div.head: To his much honoured, beloved, respected, and judicial friend ▪ master Robert Hayman.
div.p: Sir, I must needs discharge two epistles upon you the one the readers, that should be like hail shot ▪ that scatters and strikes a multitude, the other dedicatory, like a bullet, that aims only at yourself: if either do strike you, it shall be at your choice, whether I shall hit you in the head, to let you understand my meaning, or in the heart, to make you conceive my love: yet I must confess, I had rather express my love out of the flint, than my meaning in any part of the shot. I aim at you rather than the reader, because since our travails I have been pregnant with desire to bring forth something whereunto you may be witness, and now being brought a-bed if you please to be godfather, I doubt not but this child shall be well maintained, seeing he cannot live above an hour with you, and therefore shall entreat you, when he is dead, he may be buried deep enough in your good opinion, and he shall deserve this epitaph:
Here lies the child, who was born in mirth, against the strict rules of all childbirth: and to be quit, I gave him to my friend, who laughed him to death, and that was his end.

div.head: The prologue
div.l: Our author's pen, loves not to swim in blood,
He dips no ink, from out black Acheron:
Nor sucks invention, from the depth of hell,
Nor crosseth seas to get a foreign plot.
He taxes no goddesses for foulest lust,
Nor doth disclose the secret scapes of Jove:
He rips not up the horrid maw of hell,
To show foul treasons hideous ugly face.
Nor doth he touch the falls of mighty Kings,
No ancient history, no shepherd's love.
No statesman's life, no power of death he shows.
He only strives with mirth to please each one,
Since laughter is peculiar unto man.
And being sure, freely to speak can be no sin,
If honest words have honest construing.
Therefore to fly the least cause of offence,
He only finds but words, you find the sense:
Wherefore, if ought unto your ear taste tart,
Thank but yourselves, which good to ill convert,
Yet this he ought, hath strictly charged me say:
That he's a slave, and of a base condition,
That doth but draw it to suspicion.
That here he privately taxeth any man,
Since all the world yields vice to play upon.
What he intends, action shall make you know,
I should forestall the play, should I but show.

div.head: The scene in London.
div.l: With feathered speed I pierced the air,
The clouds asunder I did tear,
And thus with wings and bow come I
Newly from Jove's high court in sky.
My mother kissed me at our parting,
But did charge me leave my darting,
And with a strict command did say,
Boy, on a whirligig go play.
But such a round I'll make him run,
As he shall end, where first begun.
My scourge-sticks shall be made of darts,
Feathered with sighs of lover's hearts.
Which made them fly with swiftest flight,
As lightning in tempestuous night.
My scourge itself, are golden tresses,
More richer far than chains of Esses.
With which I'll make some dance a jig,
More rounder yet then ere did Gig.
But time doth call me to be gone,
Yet first to all you lookers on,
Before I part, I thus much tell,
That gods can go invisible.
And though you do not all times eye me,
Yet know at all times, I am by ye.
And be assured, and do not think
But that you stand full never the brink
Of my displeasure: which if ye win,
In love I'll make ye sink or swim.
Thus farewell all, sit patient yet a while,
Lest Cupid make yourselves, yourselves beguile.
div.stage: Enter the old lord Nonsuch alderman venture, sir Timothy troublesome.

sp.speaker: Venter.
sp.p: My lord, you know yourself and I have long lived friends, and shall we now with firm affection knit? tie fast our friendship in our offsprings love, convey our cares in one, our goods together, and our loves in them, and whiles the remnant of our aged days do last, let's doff all discontents, cast by the world's encumbers, and leave the careful burden of keeping that, was care enough to get upon the youthful hope of their more able strength.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: O neighbour venture, do you not know that to marry a child, is but to mar a man? for he that cuts a tender twig in springing, both mars his length and spoils his growing: my son shall first see twenty years of age, before my condescent shall once be given to make him father of a son: besides, your daughter yet is very young: and though in women's sex 'tis always seen, desire to marriage rides always in post; yet in their inn repentance is their host: the fault of this is always known to be, through foolish husbands: or such as are too young, for children to their wives are like fruit half ripe, they yield no taste, nor give no sweet delight.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: Behold, here comes my young lord, the very model of yourself, the vigour of your youth, and strength of all your future hopes.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: And he is welcome, what sudden gust (My son) in haste hath blown thee hither, and made thee leave the court, where so many earth-treading stars adorns the sky of state? or as the summer's speckled flowery garment is spread about the seat of majesty? what is the reason thou hast left this earthly paradise, to visit us before our expectation?

sp.speaker: Young lord.
sp.p:
My love dear father (To your fair wife)
hath made my hours of absence from this place, seem tedious years, I could not but return from whence I came, as like to man, the which of clay was framed, at first did walk a while upon the earth, but in the end returned to dust; or like a river, which through the earth doth draw his life and spring from out the sea. Thus I that from you sprung, have run my course awhile, but now as to my sea, return to you again.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: Thy answer with thy wisdom hath enriched thy welcome: dear friends, I pray you set your hands to this my deed.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: I do my lord, with all devoted love.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And I which hate my wife his mistress: his welcome home, will breed my ill at home, I breed my horns as children teeth, with sickness and with pain: and yet I will with as smooth a face as my wife will give me leave, make show of welcome. Sir, I much rejoice to see you, and doubt not, but ere long, you'll come and see where my poor house doth stand.

sp.speaker: Young lo.
sp.p: Or else I were unworthy of your love if I neglect the visitation of so kind friends as yourself and my dear mistress.

Visitation! my wife's not sick, what visitation? 'tis I am ill, 'tis the horn plague I have, I am sure that's not god's visitation, yet they are the lords tokens, for he hath sent them me: but marry when you will, I'll try and you be a chandler, I'll see if you'll take your own tokens again: well, but in the mean time, I am marked for death, yet he'll be in the pit before me. O that I should be a cuckold! A creature of the last edition, and yet of the old print.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: O sir, what make you here, when there's a gallant gentleman newly come from court, talking within with my lady.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p:
Yet more courtiers, more gallants, more gentlemen?
now in a hundred thousand horned devil's names, what makes 'a there? what is a gone to bed to your lady? doth a cuckold me in mine own house, in mine own chamber? nay in mine own sheets? what he's come to visit her to, is a not, ha? But let me see, I have now found out a trick to know if my wife make me a cuckold, I will geld myself, and then if my wife be with child, I shall be sure I am a cuckold, that will do brave i'faith, God a mercy brain.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry that I cannot with that free scope of friendly entertainment, give welcome to your worth, because a jealous spirit haunts my husband, which doth disturb us all, this devil hath long vexed him, and he as long vexed me, and were I not composed of more than of an ordinary female spirit, the burden of his wrongs would tire me quite.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: I cry ye mercy sir, I did not see ye.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: A man would think ye saw me, for I am sure ye have hit me right enough.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: I pray sir be not angry, I have not any way offended you, nor would —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Nay, nay, though I be, ye may be friends again with me in spite of my teeth, for look ye sir: my wife and I are but one, and then though I fall out with you, you may fall in with her.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Sir, I come not to offend you, nor —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Nay, nay, ye may, ye may i'faith, ye may, my wife is charitable, and would be glad by such a means to make us friends.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Sir, then know, I scorn my eyes should stand as witnesses unto your ladies' wrongs, and let you go unpunished: slight see a sweet lady abused!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Sir you shall not touch him, husband you are to blame, your madness makes you much forget your manners, and wrongs my his birth, to make me the only cankered, and worm eaten branch that sprung out of my fafathers
noble stock. No, no, know that the tree from which I grew, brought forth good fruit to all, not bad to you: but hence forth I'll shake hands with mirth; and entertain a careless humour: for look ye sir, the devil gives this jealousy to man, as nature doth a tail unto a lion, which thinks in heat to beat away the flies, when he doth most enrage himself with it: but come sir, will ye be my servant, my cipher, my shadow, or indeed any thing?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Your shadow if you please, and you my substance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ay, I warrant her with all her heart, and now must be do as all shadows do, when night comes, creeps into the substance.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Say 'a doe, d'ye here husband, I hear do vow before all the watchful guard of heaven, that I have lived as true unto thy bed, and chaste unto thy love, as ere was turtle to her mate: but hence forth ceremonious custom shall not curb me of delight, let her be bridled by opinion, whose weak desires cannot break her reins: for my part, I'll make you know my will is like a flint, smooth and cold, but being hardly strooken, sparkles forth fire even in the strikers eyes: I am a shamed that I have said thus much, yet I may lawfully speak, for why? come sir, will ye walk? the proverb says, give losers' leave to talk.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O wages, wages, oh honest wages! what other gallants come to your lady in my absence?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Truly sir, sometimes there comes a proper young gentleman one master Woodlie.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Would lie! with whom would he lie good wages?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p:
Why with my lady sir, and he could get her good will: but he is a gentleman I can assure ye sir, for he walks always in boots, but in troth his gentility is something decaying, his boots are on their deathbed, for their
souls are upon parting, and I think he be a soldier too, for his sword and his hangers are more worth than all his clothes, and a is a very proper man, for he is as tall as one of the guard, and he will come sometimes and take my lady by the hand, and pump for wit half an hour together.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: How dost mean, pump, ha!

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Why sir, thus he will take my lady by the hand, and wring it half an hour together, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Is that pumping for wit?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: O sir I, for he that wrings a fair lady by the hand, and says nothing, doth but pump for wit, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: A most witty exposition, of what years.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Faith sir he's indeed a man of no ears, for 'a hath been on the pillary.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: But what makes the crop-eared stallion with my wife then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Alas nothing but lies with her, and she lies with him, would you have any more?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: More! no, too much by heaven, nay then 'twas past suspicion, passed doubt, past jealousy, is not my hairs turned all to horns? am I not a monstrous and deformed beast? my wife's a goddess (Though not Diana) she can transform: I branch wages, I branch, do I not? am not I a goodly screen for men to hang their hats upon.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Why sir? ye are no cuckold:

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No? no cuckold? he lies with your lady, and your lady lies with him, yet I am no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why no, give me but attention, and with a word I'll wipe away your horns.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No, no, words are too weak to wipe them off, when deed have put them on.

sp.speaker: Wag,
sp.p: But hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Knight ▪
sp.p: With open ears to swallow comfort.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I met my lady and he fast by the garden wall, and asking for your jealous worship, they both replied you were not jealous, this spoke they both together: in this, you know they both did lie together, and yet made you no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ha! meanest so?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Even so indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Nay, than I cry ye mercy wife, i'faith she yet may chance be honest.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O sir, very honest as a pretty sempstress, or a poor waiting gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well wages, if I be a cuckold —

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, what will ye do if ye be?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What will I do? I'll make it known, for I will be a citizen, and so be a subject for poets, and a slave to my own wife, therefore follow me wages, I will do't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
O grief! how thou tormentest me, it dwells in mine eyes, feasts on my blood: swims in my tears, and lodges in my heart. O heaven! have I deserved this plague? O husband! why shouldst thou use me thus? was not my behaviour unto thee as soft as down, as smooth as polished crystal, I and my love as clear? was I not like a handmaid, even obedient to thy very thoughts? did not my nuptial duty like a shadow follow the very turning of thine eye? Oh! thou once didst love me, but thy love was too hot, and like to self consuming fire, it burned out, and how soon, 'tis turned to cold ashes, and therefore henceforth I'll seem jealous of him: for since all endeavours fail, I'll now try if jealousy can drive out jealousy: and here is fit occasion for to work upon: why how now husband, wooing of another wife before my death, whence comes this? in my conscience 'tis a plague that Cupid hath lain upon me for sleeping
cross-legged in your absence. What, are ye grown as weary of your wife as of a foul shirt? must ye be changing?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Good madam be patient.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Patient! no, you are his patient, and he is your physician, a minister's to ye (With a morbus Gallicus take ye both) I pray forsooth let me be your butler, and scrape your trenchers, since I am already fain to live of your leavings.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Woman, art jealous?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Because you give me cause: but man are you jealous?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Because thou givest me cause.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: True, false, thou hast been false indeed, abused my bed, infected even my very blood, and made it grow to hard impostumes on my brows: hast thou not wantonly, changed naked embracements with strangers? abused thy nuptial vow? hath not thy unsatiate womb, brought forth the bastardy of lust to call me father? but I'll abandon thee, disclaim that, and hate ye both.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: D'ye hear me sir, upon my conscience you do wrong your lady.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: If I wrong her, you'll do her right, I bear a blow of yours, the which I never felt, you are like a man's tailor that works with open shop for the husband, but if you chance to do any thing for the wife, you must do it inwards, inwards! you are a good workman, I must needs say't: you have fitted my wife's body, how sa'y wife, has 'a not?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Not, but you can even in my sight cast amorous glances on others: you have forsook my bed, abhorred my presence ▪ and like a man passed grace and shame, strut like a pimp before a wanton feather waging minks at high noon: besides, did not I find thee kissing of thy maid?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Did not I find thee in private conference with my horsegroom?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Didst thou not offer thy maid a new gown, for a night's lodging?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Didst not thou give a diamond to the butler?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Didst not thou send a bowed angel to thy laundress daughter?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No 'tis false.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes, 'tis true, and then when I told thee on't, thou swarest 'twas out of charity, because the wench was poor, her father an honest man, and her mother a painful woman: for these and these causes you were kind unto the daughter, great whilst I was contented to believe, because I was unwilling, like a faint hearted soldier to look of mine own wounds, until I saw thou daily woundst my love a new, and slewest thine one reputation.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Art mad?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No, but a little jealous like you, I will no longer maintain thy, sanguine sin, sooth lust with patience, nor in broken singing language flatter thy folly, as sweet heart do not wander: for I do love thee dear as doth a goose her gander: a goose indeed for if ought but a goose, I should a sought revenge for wrongs.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What art drunk?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No, for I have sufficient reason, too much knowledge, and sense enough to feel my wrongs: why should we women be slaves to your imperfections? have we not souls of one mettle, are we not as free born as you? are we not all Adam's offspring? did not you fall as well with him as we, and shall we be still kept down and you rise?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p:
Dost hear? ye are a sort of uncertain giddy wavering, tottering tumbling creatures, your affections are like yourselves, and yourselves like your affections, up and down, like the tucks on your petticoats, which you let fall and take up as occasion serves: I have seen of your sex fall in love with a man, for wearing a handsome rose on
his shoe: another fall into the passion of the heart, to see a man untie his point, to make water: a third fall into the shaking ague for eating a body cherry with two stones, and yet you'll 'Be fellows, even with the very image of your maker: but wilt let me alone, and i'faith I'll be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: alone ! faith no.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Then I'll leave thee, since I know 'tis folly beyond madness, to make her pleasure cause of my sadness.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Believe it lady, this was well done, and like a lady of a high birth: make your husband know his advancement.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
O shadow, shadow, I would have you know I would not wrong him for all the seas drowned riches: for if my heart of blood should do it as he supposeth it doth, even that blood would like a traitor write my faults with blushing red upon my cheeks: but because I (As all women and courtiers do) love good clothes which his eyes wear, yet he upbraids me, swearing 'tis to please the multitude, and that I spread gay rags about me like a net to catch the hearts of strangers: if I go poor, than he swears I am beastly, with a loathed sluttishness: if I be sad, than I grieve he is so near: if merry, and with a modest wantonising kiss embrace his love, then are my twistings more dangerous than a snake's, my lust more unsatiate than was Messalina's: yet this from jealousy doth always grow. What most they seek they loath'st of all would know. But now to you dear cousin, forgiveness let me ask, and pardon for my fained jealousy, and take but thus much of my counsel. Marry not in haste, for she that takes the best of husbands, puts but on a golden fetter, for husbands are but like to painted fruit, which promise much, but still deceives us when we come to touch: if you match with a courtier, he'll have a dozen mistresses at least, and repent his marriage within four and
twenty hours at most, swearing a wife is fit for none but an old justice or a country gentleman. If ye marry a citizen (Though ye live never so honest) yet ye shall be sure to have a cuckold to your husband. If a lawyer, the neatness of his clerk will draw in question the good carriage of his wife. If a merchant, he'll be venturing abroad, when 'a might deal a great deal more safe at home: therefore come cousin come, let's home, and this take of me, that amongst the best there's none good, all ill: she's married best that's: wedded to her will.

sp.speaker: Young lo.
sp.p: They say Cupid is a boy, yet I have known him confute the opinion of all your phylosphers: for they hold every light thing tends directly up: but I think all know he makes every light wench, fall directly down. Well I am sure 'a hath knocked me with his bird bolt, for the which Venus give him correction; for I do already love a lady of an imcomparable delicacy, but she's another man's, and will shut her ears as close to keep out charms, as great men do their gates, to keep in alms. Yet I have no reason to despair, for I have kissed her, and the French proverb says, fame baissee est demi ioyee, a woman kissed is half enjoyed: but I fear he means but the upper half.
I have here a letter must work a strange thing, and yet no miracle, it must make a lady love her friend better than her own husband.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Save ye my lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O wages! what tennis-ball has fortune taken thee for, to toss thee thus into my way?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I hope ye will not strike me into any hazard of my life though.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But what's the news my lad, what's the news? how doth sir Timothy troublesome, that jealous knight thy master.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, 'a doth with his wife like a cowardly captain in a town of garrison, fears every assault, trembles at the battery, and doubts most, least the gates should be opened, and his enemy let in at midnight.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now in the name of destiny who fears 'a?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: O sir ▪ next to you self, none so much as your courtier, for even with venomed breath, 'a speaks of them: for saith he, have but a suit to one of them, and they are like jordans, which though ye open the floodgates of your bounty, and fill them to the very brim, yet they'll always stand gaping for more.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But dost thou think his lady honest?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: As woman's flesh may be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But she has been a courtier, and therefore knowing most good, methinks she would commit least ill.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O sir, I will not but with sanctified and hallowed thoughts, touch Sinthia's brightest beams, whom all eyes do adore, and hearts do worship: where purest chastity doth shine in spotless robes of splendent majesty, where nature emulating heaven to make her even as fair as she is virtuous, but yet I well could wish, you know thatin the sky of court are many stars, the which at midnight shoot and fall.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True, through most of the twelve signs, for they shoot from their husbands at Aries (Which governs the head) and fall at Scorpio, and so indeed they shoot from top to tail: but honest wages, will ye bind me to y'

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I think sir 'twill not be so much for your health, as if I should keep you sollable.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I mean in courtesy good wages.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: O the the very name of good wages, will make a servingman do any courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Then be friend me thus, deliver this letter to your lady's own hand, with as much secrecy as ye may, and
take this for your employment.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: As secret as she that sells complexion: none but the chambermaid shall know it.

div.head: Actus secundus scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter lady alone with a letter.
div.p: Ye have your eyes like sunne-glasses, catched the heat of my beauty, and cast it on your own heart, and doth your sighs like bellows, make it more inflamed? then spend your tears to quench it, for my chaste blood's honour shall never do it. Lust, it's like an over-swollen river, that breaks beyond all bounds: it's a devil bred in the blood, nursed in desire, and like a salamader lives in a continual fire: it sprouteth larger than the ivy, which embraceth, twisteth and entangleth every one within his reach, and makes no choice betwixt the goodliest cedar and the stinkingst elder: it's a foul usurper on the name of love, and reigns with greater domination then an emperor: it's a very leprous itch, it stains, and leaves a fouler spot upon the soul than tears can wash away: but my chaste thoughts shall watch mine honour: I'll muster up my prayers to fight against temptation: shall I that have been a commander of myself, now prove a slave to sin? No, no, my mounting thoughts do soar too high a pitch to stoop to any stranger's lure. Say that a peevish fly entangled were within my never-shorn tresses, should I to save his life, cut and deform me of so rich an ornament? What though the lord Nonsuch within my love entangled be, must my honour now be clipped to set him free? No, no, my saw is this and ever shall: he that on hope doth climb doth often fall. But what shall I do? 'a writes here a will come: wit of a woman now assist me, oh apron strings be now auspicious, for here's my husband, something I must do: I have't.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now fair mistress: this is strange to find you here alone:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not alone, but environed and accompanied.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: With many heart-biting thoughts, which like Actaeon's hounds have almost slain myself ▪ yet now my constancy shall prove a glass, in which yourself shall see your own errors: the lord Nonsuch which you have long suspected, with unrebated edge of lust, hath aways sought, (I must confess) to cut my very reputation's throat, and this night —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I this night, but hear me husband:

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No no, cuckold me, kill me with grief, do, do, and when I am dead marry him: 'a has made you a jointure already of breech down: well wife well, I married you out of the country, but you have learned the city fashions already: I am a cuckold, I am, but ignorance that I was to marry thee so young, not being able scarce to put thine own apparel on.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I was the fitter for a husband, ye might then a been sure to have taken me a-bed at all times,

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: True, so might other men too.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No, ye are deceived husband, other men never lie with a man's wife but when she is ready for them, but to the purpose: this night have I promised the lord Nonsuch 'a shall enjoy my love, for which cause he will send a certain pander before, for fear you stand a rock in his way, on which all his hopes will suffer shipwreck. Now this same panderly pilot shall be by you bribed to stand sentinel, and give the watchword when 'a comes, that you may then punish him, either with death or fear.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O shallow and womanish invention, as if he would betray his master.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Tut money often times corrupts a good, disposition and makes a knave ride post to hell.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: But is this true? art honest indeed? come hither, dost love me, dost? nay but tell me true, dost?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Or else in hatred let me ever live.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Do not flatter me, I scarce believe thee, thou never kissest me but with such an affection, as a young wife doth an old husband wringing her lips, and making a mouth as if she were taking a potion.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You distaste me much sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Dost not distats me too sometimes, tell me true?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nothing but your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well prithee forgive me and let's go, but I'll so swinge my lord a h●r son Otter, I'll teach him fish in other men's ponds.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Did you deliver my letter?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: With secrecy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To herself?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Her own hands.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Made she any answer?

sp.speaker: W●.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What other news then rides on the back of report?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why they say sit that mistress correction the midwife is turned hermaphrodite .

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why hermaphrodit?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, she is become a midwife, for as your hermaphrodit hath two members the one to beget, the other to bring forth, so hath your midwife too means, the one to bring you to beget, the other to bring it forth when 'tis begotten: and look you sir, hear she appears upon her q.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O prithee do thou board her as she passes by.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Who I board her? by this light I dare not.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Then I will: fairly met fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth I have been, by my truth I see he is a fine spoken man.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: whereabouts is your house fair lady?

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: Here fast by sir, not above a couple of stone's cast off.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What gentlewomen have ye at home?

sp.speaker: Mistress C●r.
sp.p: O master wages, how d'ye? faith sir I have nobody at home but mistress Punckit, you know her well.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What's she?

sp.speaker: Mr. C.
sp.p: Truly sir a very courteous gentlewoman, and she loves to act in as clean linen as any gentlewoman of her function about the town, and truly that's the reason that your sincere puritans cannot abide to wear a surplice, because they say 'tis made of the same thing that your villainous sin is committed in, as your most profane holland.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Pray when was master wrestler of the guard at your house?

sp.speaker: Mi Co.
sp.p: Who he? in troth mi. Punckit cannot abide him, she swears 'a looks for all the world like the dominical letter in his red coat: no master wages no, I can tell ye I have other manner of guests come to my house then ●e: I have pensioners, and gentlemen ushers, knights, captains and commanders, lieutenants, and ancients, voluntary gentlemen, ay, and men thatwear their cloaks lined through with velvet; I entertain no mutton eating inns a court men, no half lined cloak citizens: nor flat capped prentices, no, the best come to my house, master new-come the courtier was there the other day, and truly he would have had some dealing with mi. Punckit, but that he had no siller: and yet I must needs say't, 'a would a put her in very good obscurity, for a brought a gentleman with him that would a given his word in a consumption of twenty pound, that 'a should a paid her at next meeting, and truly but that her trade stands so much upon present payment, and partly for mortalities sake, I think else she would a taken it, and yet before a went, I must needs say't, a showed himself like an honest gentleman and a courtier, for a left his periwig in pawn: but had you seen how a looked, for all the world like an ostriches egg, with a face drawn of the one side.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: What other guests have ye?

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: There comes master exhibition of the inns a court very often, and master angel-taker the counsellor comes sometimes, but mistress Punckit doth so jest with him, she swears to him as she hopes to be saved, and I may tell you sir, there's great hope on't, for truly she useth just and upright dealing with every man, but as I said, as she hopes to be saved, she would not marry him of all the men in the world.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Because she says that lawyers are like trumpeters, they sell their breath.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: She's a fool tell her, the lawyers are the pillars of the realm.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: Yes forsooth so I said but she said they were not only the pillars but the polers also, but I pray you sir of what profession are you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith of none gentlewoman, only a young gallant as you see.

sp.speaker: Mi, cor.
sp.p: A young gallant, say you i'faith, I'll quickly try that by and by, d'ye hear sir, d'ye hear?

div.stage: Putting her hand to her purrsse.

sp.speaker: Lor●
sp.p: What say you gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: I pray can you give me ten shillings for a piece of gold.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Yes that I can.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: O sir, oh sir, I perceive you are no gallant ifaith, it would go deep my friend, I may tell you for a young gallant to change three groats for a shilling, and 'twere great fish, I may tell you too, to angle for in a gallants great hose.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Hold mistress, spend that for my sake, and it shall not be long ere I will come and visit your house.

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: I thank your worship, sir, I'll be so bold as to take my deliverance out of your company.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: God be with you mistress correction.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: The like to you good master wages, but do you hear sir, I hope if your worship come to my house, if there be nobody at home but myself, though I am an old woman, yet I hope your worship will not despise age.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No, no, fear not that.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: I thank ye heartily sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: With all my heart, wages farewell, and bring but an answer of my letter; and I will be thy paymaster, not thy debtor.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I understand so much by your name good master Newcome.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: And I am in grace too lady, what my souls sweet secretary! you are fairly met indeed, how doth old Venter thy father?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O how perfumed your courtier's phrases are: I left him in health sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O ay, they speak in print I can tell you, and though it be a sin, to rob a man of his learning yet courtiers are very seldom blamed for getting out of any men's books.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Yet I have known them steal out of them ere now.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay then you'll make a courtier a thief:

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Ay, such a one as the good thief was.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: Mass I wonder what country man that good thief was?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O, a was my countryman lady, he was a borderer on North Wales, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Indeed and so I think, for not to flatter ye, many of your country men have proved good thieves ever since: but I pray tell me, is it the fashion of your North Wales, to suffer your beards to grow onwards thus, in spite of your nose?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p:
Yes lady, all of us that are courtiers: marry before when we were poor country fellows, we suffered our
beards carelessly to grow downward, and then they grow into our mouths in spite of our teeth, now you know hair is but excrement, and for mine own part, I had rather have my excrement in my nose, then in my teeth.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I have heard most of your country men are very active men.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O lady, I have seen a youth of eighteen years in our country, would a capered ye, thus high!

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: 'T as been in a string then.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, believe it, 'a would have done it with all his heart, but he could not.

sp.speaker: Peg
sp.p: They say to, most of your countrymen are very valiant

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O ay, they terrify their enemies with patience.

sp.speaker: Nue●
sp.p: O, we make the excellentest soldiers in the world.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Ay, but they say, they cannot press a man to the wars though, in all your country.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Yes knights:

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Why knights?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: To save our landed men at home.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: I have heard, most of ye are great travellers.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Ay, for france Spain and England, and such neighbour countries, why I have been as far as Winchester myself.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis true, some of ye travail so far abroad as ye come short home many times.

sp.speaker: Reg:
sp.p: I have heard ye are all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Indeed I must confess lady, we have few beggars, and those we have, we reward according, for if he be a lusty knave, we give him a lawyer's alms, tell him of the stature: if a poor and decrepit fellow, we give him a citizen's wife's charity, cry God help him, God help him.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: By your leave master Newcome, methinks you have a pretty lace on your band

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: A pretty slight court lace, all show, all show▪

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What's this, a shirt that ye wear? else 'tis a mock-beggar with strips.

sp.speaker: N●ue
sp.p: No, 'tis a shirt lady.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What, did you make this doublet new, or else ye new made it?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Yes I made it new lady?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Believe me sir but the livings are old.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Fie, they are greasy.

sp.speaker: Nue,
sp.p: I think they are something sweaty indeed with hunting.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Hunting: why a man need not hunt far for game, what's this?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O, a salamader lady, 'tis a salamader bred with the continual heat of sweating —

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: What's your breech made all of one stuff master Newcome?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Pray why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Because methinks the soil change's hear behind

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ay, and so doth the air as well as the soil I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: What are these hose made of the newest fashion ye have at court?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Faith lady for mine own part I am no man's ape, this is my fashion, and sometimes I stand in the presence with my cloak lined through, either with velvet or with taffeta, if with velvet, I let him hang on my shoulder, making the greatest show, carry my hat here.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Now by the soul of chastity I swear, 'a is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: If any man pass by and salute me, I salute him again, but if any lady or gentlewoman glide through the presence, and cast her eye on me, as commonly they use to do on men, that makes any show or glister as I always do.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ye! always making glisters, I hold my life he is a pothecary, do you never make no suppositors sir?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p:
I keep my place of standing, carry my body
stiff and upright, blush not, am impudent enough, when perchance the heat of the lady's affection makes her take a place of standing, either against the hangings or one of the bay windows, and therewith a greedy eye feeds on my exteriors, which perceiving, I draw to her, kiss my hand, and accost her thus.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: I pray accost her anon sir, and let's stand close and trouble not true jealousy in the picture of Hieronimo, in a little volume.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: See, see how 'a looks, do you not perceive his heart beat hither?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ay, for all the world like the Denmark drummer.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace, hear what 'a says.

Forgiveness wife: oh how have I wronged thee, oh who would abuse your sex, which truly knows ye? ▪ o women were we not born of ye? should we not then honour you? nursed by ye, and not regard ye? begotten on ye, and not love ye? made for ye, and not seek ye? and since we were made before ye, should we not love and admire ye as the last? and therefore perfectest work of nature, man was made when nature was but an apprentice, but woman when she was a skilful mistress of her art, therefore cursed is he that doth not admire those paragons, those models of heaven, angels on earth goddesses in shape: by their loves we live in double breath, even in our offspring after death. Are not all vices masculine, and virtues feminine? are not the muses the loves of the learned? do not all noble spirits follow the graces because they are women, there's but one phoenix and she's a female: is not the princes and foundress of good arts Minerva, born of the brain of highest Jove, a woman? have not these women, the face of love the tongue of persuasion, the body of delight? Oh divine perfectioned, women, whose praises no tongue can full express, for that the matter doth exceed
the labour, oh if to be a woman be so excellent, what is it then to be a woman enriched by nature, made excellent by education, noble by birth, chaste by virtue, adorned by beauty: a fair woman which is the ornament of heaven, the grace of earth, the joy of life and the delight of all sense, even the very summum bonum of man's life.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O monstrous heresy, he will be damned for that error.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Nay, let him alone, for he had like to been burned for that opinion ere now, had not a friend of mine plucked the fire from the stake.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Come, let's break out upon him.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: O no good sir, though it be a thing much given to your name, yet let not us break out, let us not show such childish parts.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Save ye knight.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And bless ye lady, oh sirrah, are you there? come ye hither, what's that strange lady there?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: I think it be mistress Babee sir, master Nuecome's mistress, for she looks like an Northern lass, made of a strange fashion, something like a lute, all belly to the neck.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: So, like a lute, and you like a skilful musician have been fingering it.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: How does your good lady knight, how doth she?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well I praise hymen, and I adore my stars, she hath no acquaintance with such a female fly as you are.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: What means he by that?

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Why I think a means you are but a light housewife, but come let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Light housewife, hang him dogged cynic.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Farewell knight.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Forgiveness wife.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now the plague of Egypt light upon you all, lice devour ye ye come: hither sirrah, what's the cause you keep such villainous company?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
I keep their company most sir for good victuals,
for you keep such a villainous house, as if 'twere always easter eve, we still hope for better: and you know your cook is gone already sir, for fear 'a should forget his occupation with you. Besides sir, if any man come to your house to dinner though he hop upon one leg, yet every man saith 'a comes to fast, and for mine own part sir, you have given me nothing since I came unto you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O thou pampered lade! what wouldst thou have? what wouldst thou feed on quails? art thou not fat? is not thy neck brawn, thy leg calf? thy head beef, and yet thou wants meat.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: No sir, but I would willingly have some wages.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well, I'll think on't, and so go call your mistress.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Look you sir, here she comes without calling.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Save your honesty then, and be gone without bid ding.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: I vanish sir.

sp.speaker: Kn●:
sp.p: Do so: oh my sweet wife, my selected spouse, the very vessel of chastity, filled to the very brim with Hymen zeal and nuptial duty: how have I abused thee? but I have washed repentance even in tears, and in thy absence I have dedicated sacred sighs unto thee to appease thy wrath: therefore tell me sweet wife, when comes this pander, when comes he?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I muse he stays so long, he should a been by promise here an hour since, and look here 'a comes?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O you are welcome sir, welcome i'faith, but when comes your lord? is he at hand, wil a come?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My lord sir, what lord?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Nay, come, come, make not the matter strange man, my wife hath told me all, you are an honest man, hold, hold, will ye but be friend me now, and watch another door unto my house, and give me notice when 'a comes, while I watch this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O now I see the trick on't, his wife hath gulled him with a lie and made him believe I am but a poor servingman only to enjoy my love: oh kind woman! O sweet lady! nay now I see she loves me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O excellent wife, how true she told me, what a beast have I been still to wrong her with suspect.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith sir I see ye are a very worthy gentleman, and for mine own part I shall be glad to do you any pleasure, for to tell you true, I think my lord means to cuckold you indeed.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why that's well said, hold hears one angel more, and go but with my wife, she'll show you the other door while I watch this: and if a come, knock him down, kill him, and lay the fault on me, I'll please you for your pains, look, here's a club will hold.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Give me, give me, come.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Go wife, go with him, see a stand stiffly to't, and if occasion serve.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I warrant ye husband, fear it not, but I'll do my part.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why that's well said, and if a come to this door, I'll teach him come to tie his mare in my ground, but what a slave have I been still thus to suspect my wife, I could never feel any horns I had, and yet I know my scull is so thin that if my wife should a cuckold me with the least thing in the world, yet my horns would a grown through now am I for my lord.

div.stage: Enter lord and the lady at another dors.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Now fair mistress, this far through the mouth of danger am I come and made my passage e'en through her life. devouring jaws to feast mine eyes upon this beauty, which makes me think all danger's but a sport, so you receive and wrap me in your love's embracements, and take hold of this fair occasion, for well you know your husband's jealousy will turn this proffered time like fortune's wheel, and drown our fairest hopes even in despair, if you be tedious in our love's effects, and therefore since your wit hath safely plotted my arrival here; proceed even to the utmost lists of my desire, and make me happy in the fruition of your long desired love.

O my lord, shall a smile, a good word, a little kind behaviour, or the title of dear servant, make your hopes to swell into so great a sea of lust, as presently to overflow and drown the honour of your mistress? O my lord no, your judgement much deceives you of my disposition: besides, I sent not for ye, it was your lewd unbridled will, that made you thus come gallop hither: yet by my means I must confess as yet you are unknown, and in some sort I glad your being here, only to make you know, that neither fairest occasions nor greatest persuasions shall ever make me violate my faith to him I owe my love; no my lord I know I durst to trust myself against the most of opportunity and strength of all temptation, and though my husband watch you at the door, yet know within, my conscience watcheth me though he be blinded with a trick, yet the clear all-light giver's eyes do see: therefore good my lord be gone, you see my husband is wilful bent, and if he chance to know you, I much doubt your safety.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But is this my pains requital and my love's reward?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Alas my lord, what would you have? my love is not mine own.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well, farewell lady, you may repent this yet ere long: yet peace fond breath, least threats my plots beguile: vengeance intended policy, must smile.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Are ye going sir, are ye going, what will not your lord come▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I think not sir, his hour is passed long since, some other business hinders him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: God's my passion, what do I see, this is he, I see his chain: nay but look you sit, when will you come again? by this light I see his signet ring.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Assure yourself sir, I'll bring you notice before my lord come.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p:
Nay, but will you sure? shall I trust to you? for look ye sir, and if you should not come, pray stay a little,
methinks your band is torn.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: It's no matter no matter.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No, 'tis not now I sent, by this hand 'tis he, 'tis he, what should I do, now if I should strike him, he would be too hard for me, for he is better armed than I.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well 〈◊〉 I'll take my leave of you, till your occasion shall need my presence.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Fare ye well sir, I hope that shall be never: but have not I spun a fair thread think you, to be a very bawd, an arrant wittal, to give them opportunity, put them together, nay hold the door the whilst this is my wife's plot, by which I have sailed to cuckold's haven yet my sail was but a smock, which she herself hoist up alas alas, gentlemen do you not know the philosopher saith this world is but a stage: hodie mihi, cras tibi my part today, it may be some of yours to morrow why 'tis but matrimonial chance, we that are cuckolds should be wisest men, for no men else do know their ends, but we know ours, for we are forked at both oh thou powerful and celestial Jove! strike down from heaven some congealed bolts of thunder, that it may pierce the womb of earth, and through it send thy lightning flames to make hell hotter than it is, or with Egyptian damps and rotten jaws renovate thy eating plague of life, dissolve nature, consume earth, destroy hell, and damn woman I beseech thee into a deeper dungeon than the devil. They fill men with diseases, and give the wan-eyed sun of heaven cause to smile to see our pains: shall the gaping of graves, the scritching of ghosts, and cries of damned souls, yet longer be deferred? shall time incorporate with sin, and beget more mischief? shall hell be better furnished with women then with devils? infernal Lucifer will muster up his female souls against thy deity, unless thou do abridge the course of sin by cutting off the increase of women, and then we shall have no more cuckolds. Come ye hither wife, come ye hither, pray tell me one thing true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: True: why husband, I'll lie for no man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Yes, for his pleasure that is gone.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: For his pleasure, why for his pleasure?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Because you are a punk wife, a punk.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now Jove bless me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: You are a cockatrice wife, a cockatrice

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now heavens defend me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: You are a whore wife, a whore.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir, the man is mad.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ay, horn mad, ah thou vile perfidious, detestable, lascivious, unsatiable, luxurious and abominable strumpet, was it not enough to be an Actaeon, a cornuto, a cuckold, but to make me a bawd, a pimp, a pander?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What pimp? what pander?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What pimp? what pander? why was not this the lord Nonsuch? did I not see his chain, nay prithee say 'twas not he, nay swear it too: over shoes over boots, since ye have waded to the belly in sin, nay now go deeper even to the breast and heart.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray hear me husband.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What vile excuses canst make, how canst thou hide thy lust? wouldst wrap thy sin in perjury to muffle up thy villainy?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nay good husband for pity's sake hear me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Talk not of pity, pity is deaf and cannot hear the poor man's cry, much less a strumpet's.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: For charity hear me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Charity is frozen and benumbed with cold, it cannot help thee, dost kneel? dost kneel? to the heaven's not to me yet they look thy heart should stoop, and not the knee. Dost weep dost? Rise, rise thou strumpet, go out of my sight, in, in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I go, yet this my comfort, in the gall of life, suspicion never wronged a truer wife.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ho, wages!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Come heather wages, my old resolution is come on me again, and it shall make me do much, for I will geld myself.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Alas sir that's the only way to make you do little.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Therefore go fetch me the operator.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What's he sir?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: The stone-cutter.

sp.speaker: Wag
sp.p: O you mean the sowgelder.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O! ●he's an excellent fellow, he takes away the cause of a man's beastly desires.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ay, and of their manly performance too.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: He makes a man not care a rush for a woman.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No, nor a woman care a straw for a man.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Doth not such a fellow deserve commendations?

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Yes as a hangman doth, for cutting off the traitors that makes the flesh rebel.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wages I do now more doubt my wife's honesty then ever, therefore I'll make him the touchstone of her reputation.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Faith sir ye might get easier touchstones than he a great deal, there's many a goldsmith's wife in Cheapside could help you to a better.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: He deserves much praise.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ay, as your cockatrice doth for the dismembering of men.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: If she be a punket I'll not be divorced.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Why should ye? why ye cannot keep more gentlemanlike company: besides, your punk: is like your politician, for they both consume themselves, for the common people. And your punk of the two, is the better member,
for she like a candle to light others', burns herself.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well wages, come follow me, for I am resolved to try my wife's honesty.

div.head: Actus Ter. scaena prima
div.stage: Enter young Nonsuch like a begging soldier.

sp.speaker: Young lord.
sp.l: Venus lay where Mars had found her,
And in warlike arms he bound her,
Cupid cried, and Vulcan spied:
And thereon threw the Sciclops,
But his horn, begat his scorn,
With all the little god's mocks.
sp.p: Now some honest gentleman pass by that I might sell him the maidenhead of my occupation for a half penny mass, here 'a comes, 'a shall have't, ye faith.

Worshipful gentleman, look with your eye, and pity with your heart the distress of a martial man, I have been a man in my days, and acquainted with better fortunes than I now see: time hath been I have born arms, but now one's gone, and I can no longer write gentleman: wherefore if you please to bestow but one poor thistle of your bounty to prick the blister of my poverty, it would set my slender fortunes a float, where they now lie beating on the goodwins of famine, I am none of these ludgations that beg for fourscore and ten poor men: my suit is only for myself.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Whom hast thou served friend?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: First I served in Ireland, then in holland, Braband, Zealand, Gelderland, Friesland and most of the seventeen provinces, I was at the siege of Bargon up soon, carried a pike at the entrance of sluice, and was hurt in the groin entering the breach.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Who was thy captain?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I served under the command of captain pipe.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Who, captain Gregory pipe?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No sir, captain tobacco pipe.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O, I know him well indeed, he is on the English nation, hath much employments.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I can assure your worship sir, I have seen him in very hot service, and when some of us his followers have smoked for't too: wherefore I beseech you sir, bestow something on me, for the knowledge you had of my good captain.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Go to sirrah, I fear ye are a counterfeit rogue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How rogue sir▪ though none of fortune's favourites, nor great men's minions, yet perchances as good a man as yourself: 'swounds Roguel

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Nay be not angry good friend for i'faith I love a soldier with all my heart, for indeed I have a cousin is one, would give thee something, but i'faith I have no siller, yet I give thee eighteen pence in conceit, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Well sir, in conceit I thank ye then.
Ye wages, come ye after like a clog to the heels of the old ape your master?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wages, how many pounds go to a stone of beef?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Eight sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Then I am lighter by sixteen pound now then I was, I may now lie with any lady in Europe for any hurt I can do her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: True sir, or good either.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I can cuckold no man,

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Yet any man may cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What's he wages?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Some poor soldier sir, lately come out of the low countries.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I must not now beg lame, for fear I lose his service
by it: I beseech ye good black captain bestow something of a poor soldier, that hath served his prince both by sea and land: if you bestow but one poor penny of your liberality, when the wheel of fate, turns, if the bitter frosts of poverty do not in the mean time nip my fortunes in the blossoms, I doubt not but to reciprocrate your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Vvag
sp.p: Hyda, what an excellent fellow this would make to dwell in the exchange, how the rogue prates?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 a soldier?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: I have been one some few years.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why then thou art a gentleman by profession, and 'tis a 〈◊〉 gentleman to beg.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: So I think, for I have gentleman like qualities enough: for I had rather drink drunk to purge, then take physic: but will you give me any thing sir?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: No sir my 〈◊〉 do●h 〈…〉 to give gentlemen money, for fear of 〈◊〉 them.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O, I cry you mercy good master mustard-pot.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Mustard pot! God's light, mustard Pot! and why mustard pot?

sp.speaker: Lo●
sp.p: Because thou art a saucebox.

sp.speaker: Vvag:
sp.p: Sauce box?

sp.speaker: K●.
sp.p: Go to, be quiet wages.

sp.speaker: L●.
sp.p: But will ye give me any thing sir?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No not a penny.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Come then sir, will ye walk a turn or too?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: 〈◊〉 with thee, why, art not lousy?

sp.speaker: L●●.
sp.p: I need not, I have change enough, for I have two pair of 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wert never in better fashion?

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.p: Yes, I have born the badge of honour in my days.

sp.speaker: Wag
sp.p: I 'a hath been some nobleman's footman sure.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Was thy father an alchemist that thou art so poor?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why do you not know poverty hath a gentleman ushers place, it goes bear before death.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Thy name,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Slack.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Of what religion art?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Faith I am yet clean paper, ye may write on me what ye will, either Puritan or protestant.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wilt thou serve me?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: So you will give me wages.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Yes that I will, and thou shalt wear my livery too, I'll give it thee, thou shalt not buy't thyself.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O mistress correction! How do you?

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: I thank ye good master wages, and how doth that goodly gelding your master?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why gelding?

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: Because he hath both abused and accused one of the most virtuous ladies that ever frizzled her hair.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace, speak soft, that's he.

sp.speaker: Mi Co:
sp.p: Is that he?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Mi Co.
sp.p: Now by my troth I am glad to see your worship in good health ▪ and how doth your good worship: lord you look ill, a body may see what grief will do: oh had you had a good wife, your worship would look twenty years younger than you do, 'tis even pity of her life that would wrong such a sweet man: what an excellent complexion your beard's off, and by my troth 'a keeps his colour very well.
What now you saucy companion you, what ail you trow?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: You had an ill midwife mistress, she hath not closed your mould well behind.

sp.speaker: Mistress Co●.
sp.p: Marry come up Jack an apes father-in-law , what can you tell?

sp.speaker: Sl●.
sp.p: I felt it by giving my hand to bid it farewell.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: O sir, that's sign ye are a clown, if ye had been a gentleman ye would a kissed it, and a taken your leave on't, I pray master wages what's this fellow?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: A new man of my masters, and I can assure you a tall soldier too.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: A tall soldier say you? so methinks , his clothes have been in shrewd services, for they are very dangerously wounded. Sir, and like your worship, this that you have entertained is no man, 'tis some scarecrow, and you have done very ill to take him away: the crows will eat up the corn now out of all measure, pray God we have not a dear year after it.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I know your husband well mistress correction, and mistress Punckit too, I hear she keeps her bed much, what is she not in health?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Have you such a gentlewoman lies at your house?

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, a younger brother's daughter, a kinswoman of my husbands.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: It seems he hath been acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Who he? no sir, she scorns to speak with him, unless 'twere by an attorney.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Pray how doth your husband good mistress correction.

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: The better your asking good master wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Indeed her husband is a very honest painful man sir.

sp.speaker: Mistress Cor.
sp.p: O master wages, no, no, master wages, you are deceived in him, there's never a morning but I am ready and abroad, an hour before he's up: and when he is up, as I am a living woman ▪ I can make him do nothing for my life.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No, doth he not study?

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Yes, like the clerk of a great man's kitchen, what meat he shall have for dinner.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Believe it but he is a good scholar though ▪ oh he
hath a passing head of his own.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Hath he, i he hath indeed, if he knew all, and I can tell ye he may thank me for't too, for he went to school to 〈◊〉 in my first husband's time

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Pray what was your first husband

sp.speaker: Mi, cor.
sp.p: M. Seldom the preacher an't like your worship, he preached in two of his benefices in one day, and sure was the death of him, he never joyed himself after he so overstrained his voice.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And than you married this man?

sp.speaker: Mi c.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, and truly afterwards bought him a benefice, but he hath sold it again, and I may tell you though I am no lady, yet he's called sir John every word, and for all this now he makes no more account of me then your man Mai Wages doth of an old shoe-clout which 'a never thinks off, but when 'a needs, and if he cannot find it, why any other thing serves his turn, and so he deals by me, and truly m. wages I may tell you, I mean to put him away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Away I why ye cannot put him away for this.

sp.speaker: M, c.
sp.p: Yes I warrant ye, if you can find in your heart to love and marry me, let me alone for that? I'll keep ye like a man all days of your life: besides, if the stones of the street in thecive should be too hot, for ye, and that ye dare not walk on them for fear the wicked vanities of the world should catch hold of ye, as they have done to the utter overthrow and undoing of many a good man, yet I can get my living in the suburbs, and what trade soever go down, I doubt not but mine will hold up as long as the kingdom yields either soldiers or younger brothers, which wants maintenance to keep wives of their own no m. wages, my trade is a sweet trade, little doth anybody know what comings in I have daily, I keep 3. as good featherbeds going winter and summer, as any sinner in the suburbs: besides, I warrant ye, I get above 20 pound a year in Rhenish wine, at the second hand.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Well, ask my ma. if he be willing, ye shall find me forward

sp.speaker: M: c.
sp.p: And that's as much as any woman can ask truly: and please your worship I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What is't mi. Cor. for you are very like to speed?
That I may have your good will to marry m. wages.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why you have a husband alive?

sp.speaker: Mi c.
sp.p: Ay, but I can be divorced from him, and like your worship for three several causes which I know well enough, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: If he be willing, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs.: Cor.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Hise fellow wages, pray a word we, dost mean to have her?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, I warrant thee a sound piece of her.

sp.speaker: Vvag:
sp.p: A piece, why a piece? didst thou ever shoot in her?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Who I, no: she recoils too much in the discharging for me to meddle with, but dost hear, put her away again as soon as thou canst: if thou keepe her long, if she prove not like a commodity of wood, and stink in thy hands then hang me.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well mistress correction, I could wish you go about this your affairs as soon as you may, and slack, and wages do you two follow me.

div.stage: Exeunt 3 〈◊〉 one door, and the bawd at the other.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Now by my chaste thoughts which I was mother of at nine years old, I here swear, never to be in love: yet master Newcome the courtier thinks with the wearing of a neat boot, and a clean band, to catch my love napping as Morse catch this mare, but Venus be my good speed, and Cupid send me good luck, for my heart is very light, and I fear 'tis but like a candle, burned into the socket, which lightens a little before it goes out.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I most fear 'tis like lightning before thunder, I pray have a careyehold fast.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Come, thou hast such a running wit, 'tis like an Irish foot boy. I fear 'twill rob thee of all thy 〈◊〉 and then run from thee and leave thee.
But I pray thee tell me one thing,

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I will an't be a good thing?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Hast thou thy maiden head yet?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: My maiden-head! faith I.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Come, prithee do not lie, for they say 'tis lost lying and by the strength of my little virtue, I wonder (For mine own part) to see how this foolish virginity is esteemed when there is such danger in the keeping it, for who doth not know that the barren womb is cursed? and all know virgins have no children: besides, women shall be saved by the bearing of children, how think'st thou, are they?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Nay, I cannot tell, you were best try.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Indeed they say 'tis good to try before one trust.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: But I pray thee tell me one thing now,

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: And what's that?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: The reason why thou art come run away from thy father, considering the foreman of your shop, methought was a good handsome fellow.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Tis true, so he was, but he had no leisure to keep me company a worky days for crying what do you lack, and a holy days he would be at stoolball amongst the boys when I had most need of him: but to tell thee the true cause of my coming away; I should have married a young unthrifty lord, one that will give his very soul to a fair woman, and faith sometimes though she be never so foul, yet he will lend her his body: he had never a hair on his beard this three or four 〈◊〉, but might a been an utter barrister, for they have moulted all five or six times: he's like death, he spares none, young nor old, rich nor poor, fair nor foul, he takes all.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Well Nan well, thou art happy, thou were't born under a good planet, thou hast store of suits, but prithee look, is there none hear's our counsel?

sp.speaker: Nun:
sp.p: No none, speak boldly lass.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p:
I think an ill star reigned when I was born, I cannot have as much as suitor, this master Newcome that you for sooth so much scorn: I could find in my heart to pray nine times to the moon, and fost three saint Anne's eves, so that I might be sure to have him to my
husband.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Ay, thou wouldst have him dreaming but not waking I am sure.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Not waking yea and a 〈◊〉 too, for here I vow even by the chastest thoughts that ere was nursed within Diana's breast and by those purple drops chaste Lucrece spilt, and by the unstained colour of a maiden's blush, that I will prove as true unto his bed, as ere did she that did Ulysses wed.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, since I have refused a lord, by this light I scorn to marry any under the degree of a knight.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I would not have a knight if I might, for there are so many, as they are forgotten what they be.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay I then I see you are deceived, why woman, they have most of them taken an order that they will never be forgotten, for they have booked themselves down a purpose, I know above three and twenty in one mercers books in cheap side: then judge thou how many are in all their books, and there is that will be a witness I warrant you to after ages, what their forefathers have been.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Ay, but that's but their faults, yet you know their calling is honourable though.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Faith thou sayest true, I must needs say, knighthood is like marriage know a day's, which thought be honourable amongst all men, yet it begg●●lie with a great many: but come shall's go to dinner and see what stomach I have to my victuals, for i'faith i have none to a husband: I would not taste a morsel of a men for any money.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: O that's because thou art not hungry.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, a little bit would 〈◊〉 my belly.

div.stage: Enter lady and Slacke after her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O my unkind husband, why dost reject me? if not on thee, where should I fix my love to have reward ▪

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Here where you are, in dear and high regard.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas thou art a man of mean condition.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.l: Your love to me, will breed the less suspicion.
Fortune denies me wealth: all ill upon her,
Yet I have courage to defend your honour,
Madam, you reason have to be unjust:
A wicked husband makes an unkind wife.
Men brag, that women weaker creatures be,
Yet you must suffer all gross injury,
With silence too, and lowliness of spirit,
And then forsooth a good wife's name your merit.
A goodly purchase sure to be a slave,
Unto a slave, till you go to the grave.
Eve had a soul as well as Adam,
All souls are masculine, hold freedom madam.
If strength of body make the noblest creature,
Why should not lions be the Kings of nature?
The strongest creatures governed are by sense,
And there thy soul hath little residence.
Philosophers say, the element of fire,
Is active, purest, aptest to aspire:
Of which you women have the lesser portion,
Which makes your brains beget cold notion.
I grant that Adam was created so,
But since his fall, all thinks do backward go.
Now active heart, gets murder, theft and rapine:
'Tis thy chariot which all vice doth ride in.
Against whose ille's women could temper spurns,
Give me the heart which warms not that which burns.
O hateful is the state you now do hold,
Worse than the slave, that is for money sold.
For you must money give to buy your evils,
And bind yourselves, to some incarnate devils.
Be but chief steward in their drudgery,
Bring forth their brats with your life's jeopardy.
Scarce dare you give, an old sleeve from your arm,
But they cry out, you're under Covertbaren.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Presumptuous slave whose flesh upon thy bone,
thy master just, may challenge as his own:
Which by the dead scrapes from his trencher got,
Is quickened now, to cut thy gevers throat:
Thou venomed snake, frozen with beggary,
Now being thawed by thy master's bounty.
Wouldst sting the bosom that did revive thee,
And like a viper gnaw, who first conceived thee.
Full argument of a servile spirit,
For noble hearts will gratify each merit.

sp.speaker: Sl●●.
sp.p: Yea, are ye vanished?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why how now fellow slack, what is she gone?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: 'Slife what should I do now to stop this slaves venomed breath, for fear it infect my reputation with my new master? this time was ill taken, yet something I must do fellow wages, how long hast thou been here?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ever since fortune denied thee wealth: all ill upon her: but thou hast courage to defend her honour.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: 'Slight he hath heard all.
Why man 'twas my master set me only to try her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, like enough, for I see he would willingly prove an accessary to the stealing of his own goods.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True, and look here he comes, but I pray thee say nothing, let me tell him of it.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Who I? not a word, my mouth is as close as a faulconer's pouch, or a country wench's placket.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: She would never cuckold me, but that she hath some reason for't

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
True sir, there is nothing done, but there's reason for it, (If a man could find it) for what's the reason your citizen's wives continually wear hats, but to show the desire they have always to be covered. Or why do your sempsters spend their time in pricking, and your ladies in poking of ruffs; but only to show they do as they would be done unto? or why do your inns of court men lie with his laundress in a long vacation, but because he hath no money to go abroad? Or why do your old judges widows
always marry young gentlemen, but to show that they love execution better than judgement.

sp.speaker: K●●.
sp.p: O, but I wonder much she would not give me leave to make my first child myself.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Foe: she knew you were but a prentice to the occupation, and commonly prentices spoil their first work, and being unskilful, she was loath you should practise in a good shop, and therefore she befriended you, because she would have it well done: she got a better workman to do it for you. For what's the reason the younger brothers (According to the old wife's tails) always proved the wisest men, but because the fathers grew more skilful at last than they were at the first? but I think your wife's eldest son will prove an excellent fellow, because she had the help of so many in the making of it. For commonly if one have a thing to be done, as a conveyance to be drawn, or a case in the law to be argued, a man would have the help of as many good lawyers as he could get: now this case of making of children, and a case in the law, is something like, for as one lawyer takes his fee, and deals in't, another lawyer comes and argues the case more profoundly: but in the end when all is done, leaves it to be tried by the jury, in whom the right is, and so must you: when they and you and all have done your best, yet in the end, must leave it to be tried by your wife, who's the child is, for a woman's knowledge in this case, is better than twelve men's.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O slack, I hate worse than the worst sin that is.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: And I pray which sin do you most hate?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: That which is most like her, which if thou wilt repeat —

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I'll tell their conditions.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And I, which is most like her.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Then the first is pride.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I would have that sin burned for a witch, it changes men into so many shape.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: The next is murder.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: O! that's a thirsty sin, for naught can quench it but blood.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What is theft?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Faith the greatest fault that I can find in that is, it cozens the scriveners, for it borrows money without giving any obligation.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Covetousness.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O! that's an excellent sin, for to deal with, a that hath a loose belly, for 'twill bind any man for ten groats.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What is sloth then?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Faith sloth is a good maidenly green-sickness sin.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: But lechery my lady?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O that's the suckingst sin that a man can be acquainted withal, it cannot endure to be in company, it creeps into corners, and hides itself in the dark still.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: What sayest then to drunkenness?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: O that's a most gentleman like sin, it scorns to be beholding for what it receives in a man's house, it commonly leaves it again at his door.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Nay, than lechery scorns to be bebolding too, for I have known what it hath received in a man's house, it hath sent home again nine months after, and lain at his door, and therefore the more gentleman like sin a great deal, because it takes the longer time of repayment, but I pray sit now, which of all this is most like your wife.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Murder, for naught can quench her thirst of lust, but now I soon shall find her villainy, praised be my vigilant care: which if I do espy, I'll turn her off.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Alas, alas sir, you have no reason to be angry, much less to be divorced, although she do transgress, are you not cut? have ye not given her cause, is it not out of mere necessity she doth it? therefore if you follow my counsel, make her amends with kindness,
and put not her away.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Believe me he speaks wisely, and good counsel, like a lady, is to be embraced.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Not put her away, and if she wrong him. If he do not, I say he is one of the arrant'st blocks that ever man spurned on: why is he not a gentleman, a knight, hath 'a not seen fashion: sir, I would have you bear a noble mind, put her away and you list, 'tis no matter for cause, if she change but a trencher with the groom of your stable, 'tis dealing enough to be divorced, therefore put her away, and than you may have another wife.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Another wife?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True, a gallant, and yet a modest lady too, one that shall nourish no blood but your own, tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, and honour even your very footsteps.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: She shall go, I'll make her truss up her trinkets, o faith she shall away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Shall she away? if she do, you do you know not what, you draw a thousand thousand enemies about your ears, her kindred they'll exclaim, no friends will seek revenge, and your enemies will grow even fat with laughter at your folly.
