Besides: what woman then will have you, are you not gelded? assure yourself that now there is none will love you, most will hate you ▪ but all will scorn you, therefore by my advice make much of her, and keep her while you have her.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ha! now by the virtue of my hearing, he speaks but reason.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: So, 'tis good to keep her still: dwell in the suburbs to break down your own glass windows, set some picks upon your hatch, and I pray profess to keep a bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: A bawdy-house? no, I'll die first, and if I see but any apparent show of her disloyalty, I'll even be divorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Well, I see the substance of this slave is villainy.
But I'll prevent him even what I can,
Since none is worse than a serving honest man,

div.head: Actus quarti, scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why had I not a good leg? did I not always wear clean lining? was not my hand washed, my beard combed, my cloak brushed, and my shoes blacked, every morning.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: True, why the more viler strumpet she to cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: But how dost know she is with child.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Know it, why she's daily troubled with water pangs, and quakings over her stomach.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Indeed I must needs say that's a great proof, she hath filled her belly with something that stood against her stomach, but dost not think 'tis my child.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Yours! why how can't be yours: are you not circumcised to the quick?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Yes, and the remembrance of it galls me.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: That's a sign ye are too patient, and like an ass endure all without resistance.

sp.speaker: K●i.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But why do you laugh sir?

sp.speaker: Kn●.
sp.p: To think who the child will be like.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why you, who should it be like else?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why 'tis none of mine man.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p:
Why the more like you for that: why do you not not know the philosophers hold the child is always like the party which the mother thinks off in the conception: now she thought most of you, for fear you should a come the whiles, and that's the reason so many gentlemen's sons are like your citizens, and calls them fathers too, for otherwise how could it be
that a young cockney being left forty or fifty thousand pounds: spends all within so many months, but that some young gallant begat him, for you know the prover be, cat will after kind. No, had the old citizen begotten him, he would a bit a fig in two, to have made just weight, and have had a pot with a false bottom, rather than a sold too much measure, he would have done all things within measure as your old citizen did, and not a spend all beyond measure, as your young gallants do.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: But were not I best go home and use her well, till the child be born, to see if it be like me, that I may be sure 'tis none of mine.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O no, that were base, and as deceitful as the colic when it breaks out in wind, which levels at a man's heel, and it strikes him in the nose, therefore never make a show of one thing, and do another, but put her away, rid your hands of her, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I think who's the father of the bastard?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why who's the father of a punk's child? is't not filius populi, it may have two fathers for any thing we know.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well slack, I do very much mistrust wages too, for he is grown very familiar of late.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True sir, and takes her part too, and ye mark him

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I mark him: no slack, no pray heaven a mark not me, but I'll instantly sue out a divorce, hap what hap shall, but ill's his hap whose wife lies down to all.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Of all honest animals your cuckold is the best,
For he is sure a gentleman, and known by his crest.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.l: Of all occupations, that ever man professed,
In my opinion still doth hold, the cutpurse is the best.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: And why the cutpurse?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Because he will trust no man, foe as soon as he hath lone his work, he is sure to have his money in his hand.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Nay then a lawyer is a better trade than that, for he
is sure of his money before he doth his work.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But I pray thee what's the news abroad now?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Why they say the world is like a bias bowl, and it runs all on the rich men's sides: others say, 'tis like a tennis-ball, and fortune keeps such a racket with it, as it tosses it in to times hazard, and that devours all, and for my part they say, 'twill shortly run upon wheels with me, for my master swears a will have me carted, because 'a thinks I have lain with my lady.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Nay then 'twill run upon wheels with thee indeed, but peace fool peace, when thou art once married, that suspect will die.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace fool peace, sayest thou when I am married? dost hear? I tell thee, there is no piece in marriage, unless it be with a dumb woman, no nor but little comfort neither.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: No way? why doth the ballad say then, so sweet a thing is love, that rules both heart and mind, there is no comfort in the world, to women that are blind.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Kind (Man) the ballet says.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Mass I think a be kind indeed, yet blinds the better of the two I think, for as thou sayest, if she be dumb, I am sure she'll say nothing that shall offend her husband: if blind, she'll see nothing that shall offend her, and where he nor she's offended, there must needs be a peace: but besides this is there no peace thinkest thou in the marriage of a wife.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes by the man's, side like a gentleman only by the father's side, but 'twill ne'er be any perfect peace.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why, why wilt thou marry then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Because I hope to have some good behaviour of my wife, for the peace I never look for: but soft ye fellow slack, methinks your suit is like a hard hearted landlord, it begins to receive great rends.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Ay, I would, my master had given me a suit of buff when he gave me this.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p:
Phoe, buff is naught man, that hath been out of request
quest ever since soldiers have been out of date, and they poor men are now used like almanacs of the last year, either clap-vp behind the door, or thrust clean out of door: but if thou wilt have a suit that shall last indeed (Lad) get thee a suit of law.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O, I do not like such suits, for commonly they that have many of them go almost naked for want of clothes, yet I cannot deny but they are very lasting, but they are subject to many discommodities: so if there be any goodness in one of them, your lawyers like moths, eat shrewd holes to it, but your country attorneys like lice never leave wrighting and wrangling till they have crept into it, but when it hath been well worn and grown thread bare, they even like lice drop off, and leave it.

sp.speaker: Vvag:
sp.p: What sayest thou by a suit at court then?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: I marry sir, I like that well, for commonly he that hath but one suit when he comes there, hath two ere he come away, for if he sue by petition, it lies so long in your courtier's pocket, that it is another suit to get his petition back again. There is none suddenly dispatched of his suit there but a tailor, marry he stays not at all, unless his suit be to have money for his suit, and so he makes his suit two suits too ere he go. But come, shall we go see what follows after our master's new divorce.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why is a divorced?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Ay, I think by this time, for he swore he would be presently. By my troth, I am sorry for it, for in my conscience it is without cause, it grieves me to see him in these humours, for I thank his worship he hath ever used me well, I am bound to pray for his life.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: And methinks that's a strange thing, I see no reason for't that any servingman should pray for his master's life, considering all that he have, is in reversion of him: but come, let's follow him, for if he miss us, he'll fret like a grogram I, and fume like a stew pot.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: And let him fume, oh would his gall would burst with indignation, then should his temper procreate my bliss, and I 〈◊〉 that saint incarnate: but what shall I do, since base nor noble shape can win, a third I'll try.
sp.l: And if that fail knight, go to church and prey,
For vengeance wings brings on thy lethal day.

sp.p: He that a long way voyage takes in hand, fears dangerous gusts at sea, and storms:

At land conquering cold that cripples cursed age, and doubts lest every cloud should prove a storm, and beat his wearied carcase to the earth. But oh, I would to God my longest journey unto death were to be ta'en, for I do cast no doubts, having lost all comfort, my son, I fear, is dead, the loss of him makes life to me but like a blister on my flesh, which grieves me much, and naught can ease, unless it breaks. O whilst he lived his presence was a force unto my age, and gave it such a luster as did enrich my ring of life: for life is but a ring beginning in our weakness, going round, till unto weakness we return again, then to the ground. The world itself is but a skilful game at chesses, which being ended, Kings and Queens, Bishops and knights into one bags are thrown at last: so all of us both poor and rich, shall in the end into the earth, as into a bag be cast-mans life is like unto a ship that crossed by tempests and by tides, some thoughts of his like billows swell him up a loft, another strikes him down, thus man as on a sea is tossed, in fairest weather fears a storm, and in a storm the event, but in the end he sinks, when life is spent: grief hath no bounds in tears, it ebbs and flows.
Till it have drowned life, and ended woes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But wages, is there no means (Thinkest thou) to turn by it, nor to force back his stream of wrath.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes I'll warrant ye madam, if you'll be ruled by me, you shall see I'll make him seek to be friends with you, and entreat me to speak for him too, but then I would have you seem a little strange: but you shall directly rail on him. Therefore I would have ye hide yourselves here behind the hangings, for 'twill not be long ere he come this way, and than you shall come forth and frame your behaviour according as our discourse shall require.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Mass here he comes, let's stand close.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: We will, and heaven assist thy projects.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now wages, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Vvag:
sp.p: That which I think will help you from being divorced.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why your lady is not with child.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why how should she, unless some hobgoblin, some incubus or spirit of the buttery should beget it? why she, since you were gelded, never saw a man but through a window: she hath never trod her foot awry, for fear some ill construction should attend her steps, which like a boundless ocean deep enraged, would drown her reputation.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Not with child sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not of my word sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wages I would thou wouldst but do some charitable offices.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What? make ye friends again?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But you'll prove false, and break that friendship?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Never, as I hope to be reconciled, therefore tell me, wilt thou do't?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Hum: truly I would do my good will, but I fear 'twill be but labour lost.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I pray thee do but try: i'faith thou shalt not lose thy pains.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: O lass sir, you know I must feed on quails.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: That was in my fury man, but wilt thou not do it?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Pray sir, if you can get some other friend to speak in 't, do.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well, thou wilt leave me now then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Alas sir, what would you have me do? by my troth sir, I am ashamed to speak in't: have ye not gelded and cut off all the content of marriage? why they that have the full performance of it, 'tis as much as they can do to please their wives, and you that want all ability, must not only please her now, but make her amends for the wrong you have done her heretofore, and how have I the face to promise that which I know you have no means to perform it?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Alas man, I'll do my good will.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Do your good will, and that's much worth sure, yet since you have been my master, the world shall not say but I'll do ●hat I can, I'll persuade what I may, ye shall see there shall be no fault in me. Enter the lady and Nan.mass here she comes: what will you do now?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O● I'll hide me here, and so I shall hear all what she says.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: O this is excellent, come, come, come, and stand close, ye shall hear how I'll speak for ye: and if ye hear your pardon granted, come forth.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Morrow madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Morrow wages.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Morrow mistress Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Morrow wages.

sp.speaker: Vvages.
sp.p: The fox is caught, his head is in the noose.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Peace, speak soft, persuade, persuade.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Faith madam I have a suit unto you, but I am half a shamed to speed in't.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: 'Slight, the rogue says he is a shamed to speak for me, hist wages, hist wages.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, your man would make an ill suitor, that is ashamed to speak in his suit.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: What the devil ail you, what are you made you'll be spied anon.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A pox on thee, art not ashamed to tell her that thou art a shamed to speak for me? hist, hist, wages.

sp.speaker: Wag●s:
sp.p: I think the fool rides you, what will you have?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Dost hear wages, speak for me, and by this light I'll mend thy wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By how much?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Forty shillings?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Three pound, three pound.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I'll do it

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But what's your suit wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: That you would forgive your husband,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What and receive his love again, you mean?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Marry there were a jest indeed, being as he is now, a woman would be loath to turn him amongst her ducks: truly Wages I am ashamed in your behalf, that a man of your discretion would urge it, therefore prithee speak no more on't, I'll tell thee what, I could find in my heart to speak for him myself, but that 'tis such a jealous fool, that if he catch but a flea in her bed, he will be searching to see if it be a male or a female, for fear 'a
comes to cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: Well wages well: to tell thee truly, I bear no malice, and if I wist he would amend, I should forgive and love him with my heart again.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ye faith I will wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why how now wages, have you betrayed us?

sp.speaker: Wag ▪
sp.p: Ay, madam, but 'tis into the hands of those that love ye.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well wages well, I did not think you would have used us thus.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is there honesty in this, to set a man behind the hangings to eavesdrop our words.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Be not angry sweet wife, i'faith it was my plot, but you have been a heavy enemy of mine.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Twas more for my credit then to have been your light friend.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Be friends with me good wife, for here I do confess.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Your jealousy sprung from your own unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then in hope you'll kinder prove, I am content, for this know, a woman's heart will soon relent.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Then, come sweet wife, let's in,
And wages, thy pains deserves to be requited,
For separated hearts, hast thou united.

div.stage: Enter Nuecome singing with a glass in his hand, and making himself ready.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: La, la, la, la, la, they marched out manly by three, and by three, and the foremost in battle, was Mary Hanbrie. Will you hear of a Spanish lady, how she wooed an Englishman: hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Is the tailor gone?

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: Gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Go fetch me my doublet their,

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: I go sir,

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, by the greatest terror to gentility, which indeed is creditors and sergeants, this roguy tailor came upon me with such a bill as a man were better have ten constables and their watches come upon him with their bills: why good words, or a dozen of ale will please them, but nothing will stop this rogues mouths but money: and yet i'faith I am greatly in his books, for though I misuse him never so much, yet the rogue durst not cross me. Enter boy.let me see boy, mass 'tis a pretty doublet.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The tailor sir, entreats you to remember your day.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: My day ▪ god's light, my day? why what doth a take me for, I think?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'A takes you for a gentleman sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: A gentleman, and remember my day, no, I'll hold my life he takes me for some merchant or citizen, but I'll make him know my strength, ere I leave him, he shall find a second Sampson of me. I can break my bond's boy, I can, I can.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: But come sir, will you try your doublet first.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O ay, come, come pluck, but take heed of my ruff I pray thee▪ this doublet is too little, a pox in him.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Not now, he is on sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: No when he is off, I mean boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Believe it sir, but it becomes ye well though.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Doth it indeed? mass I think it do, methinks I have a reasonable good leg in't.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: So you have sir, but your heel is a little too short.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Yea, why too short?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Because your long heel sir doth always best become your great calf.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Why? my calf is not very great.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: O sir yes, why a man shall not see a greater calf of your age, for I think you are not above twenty.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Not so much, but come help off my doublet now.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Come, I'll see how 'twill look here, and go thou and watch the door, that nobody come the whilst, hum, hum, hum, if I had a band for't.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why that about your neck sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: But what if anybody should come the whilst?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why do not I keep the door?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Mass that's true: hum, hum, hum.

O 'tis master Newcome, I know him, a fine gentleman i'faith I'll salute him by and by as I pass. Master Newcome I take it, I cry ye heartily mercy good master Newcome, I am glad to see you in good health sir, I shall entreat you to pardon me, I protest I did not know you in that suit, you have a very fair doubleton, the gods give you joy sir: there is never a lord in the land may be ashamed to wear it sir, rap, rap, rap, rap.
God's light carry away my doublet quickly, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I warrant ye sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: God's precious my band, what shall I do now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: By your leave sir, my mistress, mistress Peg sent to see how your worship doth.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I thank her very heartily, I pray commend me to her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I'll do your commendations sir, but I pray you be covered sir, I pray yond be covered.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I thank ye heartily, 'tis for mine ease, the weather is hot, hot, very hot.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: So it is indeed sir, well sir, by your leave sir, I'll be so bold sir as to carry your commendations sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Do so good friend, farewell, farewell.

What a beast was I to put off my band, yet the griefs the less, because he came from Peg, which is a wench I must confess dotes on my exterior virtues, but I can by no means affect her: only, because the poor wretch, in heat of her passion shall not melt herself away in tears, she sometimes enforceth me to swear and protest I affect her, marry always with mental reservations for my soul's health, for you know that sometimes it is policy courtiers and statesmen should use fallacy.

div.stage: Enter the lady with a servant.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Give charge unto the cook 'a make not too much haste with supper, for I hope your master will be here tonight , and look you keep fast the door, let no man trouble me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will madam.

sp.speaker: L●d.
sp.p: Now thanks gentle heavens, oh be you smiling still on my designs, and let your influence pour down good fortunes, and be not angry, nor no more malevolent, but make my husband's reconcilement irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir, I shall be shent for letting of you in.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Sblood I tell thee I will speak with her, what wouldst thou bar my chance when my whole fortunes lies on thecast.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O heavens, stars, fates, gods smile not like summer on these wasps no longer, that daily bussing come to sting my honour.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Save thee sweet lady, I hear thy husband is from home, which makes me come to tender thee my person's love.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Your parson's love (Sir) is most commonly a benefice, oh that I should be troubled with this ass now, do you hear sir, if my husband should come and find you here we were both undone.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your husband, your husband is an ass, by this light and he should offer you but an ill look in my sight, 'twere better he had no eyes: but 'tis your own fault that would not ere now accept of the love of a soldier, to have kept the slave in some awe.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: O! how reproachfully the captain swaggers, I'll away, for fear he grow furious.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But dost hear me sweet lady, I have loved thee long, and must now enjoy thee. Fear nothing: this warlike sword of mine shall defend thine honour, this martial blade shall do't: life it shall i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Hark, hark, my husband is come.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your husband, ha! where, where?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis not he? but I'll try my captain's valour now. O sir, my husband, what shall I do now, he hath a pistol in his hand too, he will kill us both.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pistol? cods my life, what shall I do then? I pray hide me somewhere .

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O no! as ye love me, must enjoy me, and will defend my honour, draw forth this warlike sword: this is the martial blade must do it, therefore I beseech you good captain now or never.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
God's precious woman, he hath a pistol, a sword no shield against a bullet.
receive, and then to have, hold, manure and occupy in statu quo prius, that is in the state before and I do not doubt but your grant in this case will be good, for there is a case that proves this in quinto of rich the third: a patron was seized of an advowson in fee, with two nuns appendant, and thereunto presented a parson, with a proviso, thatif the incūbent should alien grant, demise, let, set, or otherwise put away the premises, or any part or parcel thereof ▪ that then it should be lawful for the patron (Or his assigns) in and upon the whole to re-enter. The incumbent aliened, the patron entered, the quare was, whether those two nuns were any part of the premises, and by virtue of the proviso subject to thereentry: and after long dispute it was agreed by all the court, that the entry was good, as well in the two nuns, as in the rest of the premises. Then much more in this case, where we are both lay men.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sure this fellow thinks he hath some right to me, and he hopes to win me by law, but what think ye: if my husband should come and enter now upon us two, in what case were you?

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Why well enough, perchance he would complain of me to the bench, and then I should be put out of commons: that's the worst he could do, and thatis nothing; for I was once put out of commons before, for beating of the panyard man: and in again within three days after.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: O madam, madam, what will you do? my master is come as I am a living man.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O lass sir, what shall I do with you?

sp.speaker: Exh.
sp.p: Why hide me somewhere , cannot ye hide me here?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O no, no, no, he doth use to search all the house still, to see if he can find anybody here, but I'll tell ye what ye shall do, draw out your rapier and go out against him, and whatsoever question he ask you ▪ make him no answer, but only say, ye doubt not for all this, but you shall meet him and be revenged well enough in another place, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Exh:
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Come out, come out man.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Slight woman your husband will see me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Spretious man, that's all one, come out, come out, draw your sword, hold it in your hand, make some show of resistance.

sp.speaker: Captain ▪
sp.p: 'Sblood woman he hath a pistol.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: He hath none, he hath none, by this hand I did but jest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'faith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why will ye not believe me ▪ i'faith he hath not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well then, well, nay I care not if he had.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why how now wife, what's the matter? what stir have we here?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why husband did you not meet a man with a rapier drawn in his hand?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Yes, and here's another.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Alas husband, he would a killed this poor gentleman, but that he came and ran in here for shelter, and because I would not suffer him spoil him here in your house, he is gone in such a rage as you never saw.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: My faith, and he swore indeed he would be revenged in another place: did he not wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: He did indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Kn●.
sp.p: Believe me, and he might easily have slain you sir, for he had a very long rapier.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: True, I know myself he had the better weapon, or else I would ne'er a stood so against him.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Ay, had I such a rapier, I would a made him run like an Irish lackey.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ay, to have overtaken ye.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Well wife, believe me, I thank ye for this: for I would not for the wealth of all this town he should a hurt him in my house, well sir you shall sup with me: and after supper I'll conduct you to your lodging myself, but fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I thank you sir.

div.head: Actus quinti scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why did you not perceive it?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Not, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O monstrous! why did she not say herself, she knew he had the better weapon, for which cause she stood against him, meaning bawdry, flat bawdry, and yet you could not perceive it: now by this light, had you slept but one foot lighter, ye had taken them in the very fact, but you go dreaming hanging down your head, that 'tis no marvel your wife makes you a cuckold: for the husband being the wife's head, why when the head goes down thus ▪ the heels must needs mount up.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I'll never more hear of reconcilement, but be divorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Straight put her away, why you may have 〈◊〉 enough.

sp.speaker: K●.
sp.p: O wives too 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: There's your 〈…〉 Peg, she is fair, modest, honest, 〈…〉 discreet and honourable.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And would 'a be acquainted with me fall'st?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: The man thou speakest of.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why I speak of none, I talk of a woman,

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: And have all these good conditions.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Ay, why not?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Dost know her.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Hark then, rent a chamber, hang out her picture, take twelve pence a piece at the least,
sp.l: For enough will come I know:
To see that which none else can show.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: 'Slight I think the man be mad, but 〈◊〉 ye not have her sir?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p:
Yes, if thou tell true, who would not have her: but
first make winged speed to purchase my divorce, hold here's money, make haste, use no delay,
sp.l: For all men must for expedition pay.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I go, and you shall be divorced or else my brain shall sweat: for what your folly loseth, my wit shall get.
sp.stage: Exit Slacke at one door, and enter wages at the other.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O wages, I'll tell thee news, I have sent for a divorce, and what wilt thou say when I am married to a new wife?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Then sir will I say as the proverb says, marriage and hanging comes by destiny: but if ye be divorced, and will follow my counsel you shall hang yourself, rather than marry again.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: No wages, I do not hold that so good: for sure, marriage is better than hanging in some.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: True, in some respect, and that only because you have a longer time of repentance, but I pray sir, is't a christian that you mean to marry?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: A christian! Ay, why dost think I would marry a 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: I do not 〈◊〉 that so well sir, because it is the fashion amongst them to send capons to their godfathers for new years gifts, and upon my life sir, she'll one time or other clap you up in a basket, and send you away for good handsel: but I pray sir who is it?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Peg, is she not a fine gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Beyond praise.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Hath she not a piercing eye?

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: And 'twere a ferret.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: A delicate nose.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And it were a mulberry.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Teeth like two rows of orient pearl.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: But the string is broken and many of them are fallen out.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Hands as white as Pelops shoulder.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ay, and as thick too.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Go to her, and measure by thy protestations the depth of my affections: tell her what I will be to her, not what I have been to others: if she allege to thee her cousin's presupposed wrongs, tell her, I well could have been hoodwinked to her cousin's faults, so I had never seen her face.

sp.speaker: Vvag.
sp.p: But what shall I tell her if she say you are gelded?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I there's it indeed, there is no excuse for that: yet thou mayst tell her, I did it only to preserve my voice. Deliver this jewel to her hand, and with it even my heart's affection.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I will sir, and if the wenches close my projects carry, spite of mischance you shall your own wife marry.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now must I be frolic, learn to speak well, and woo with a good garb: and now I think on't, I have a pretty conceit of mine own, I will tell her that the wooing of a young wench, is the felling of a tree, and the getting of her friends good will, like the lopping of the tree, therefore first it behoves me to hew down the tree and then I'll climb with ease: but if at first to fell it I be not able, to assay to climb it shall be in vain. Welcome, hast thou brought the divorce.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: 'Tis here sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Come then, let's in, it joys me much that thou so soon hast sped,
For hours seem years, till it be published.

sp.speaker: Na●.
sp.p: But tell me good madam, why are you so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: To think upon the saucy importunity of my servant slack: he is like a badge on a coat, he is never off, off my sleeve, and yet I shun him like the pest.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And he follows you like infection.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay I would he did so by me, for I protest I love him beyond my thoughts, I covet nothing like his company, and yet he hates me, loathes my sight, but then comes the Welshman your love, and he hangs on my lips like a padlock on a pedlar's budget.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And hates me as much, for if I come but near him, he swears I am like a kybe, always at his heels.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Come madam, do not grieve at that which grief can no way mend.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I would not, if I could mend that which doth cause my grief.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: News, news.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What news.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: You are divorced.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why divorced, why? ha, speak.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot speak the cause madam? but questionless 'tis true, and mistress Peg, my master now makes love to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: To thee, I to thee, go thy ways, thou shalt be a lady, I ever thought thou wouldst come to some promotion, as the boy did that had a bag and a staff and begged for himself, but how dost thou know he is in love with her.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Know't why I have seen him stand an hour together behind an oaken tree, calling it sweet mistress, kind Peg and making speeches to it.

sp.speaker: N●,
sp.p: As how? as how? prithee how?

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Stand you for the tree, and I'll speak for my master.

sp.speaker: N●n.
sp.p: I will, and that most stiffly i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: Then thus he begins: dear mistress Peg I must confess.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay then he is a dead man already.

sp.speaker: W●.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: N●,
sp.p: Why confess and be hanged ever.

sp.speaker: Wages
sp.p: O ho, but I mean he doth confess she's 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's all one, he's but one man, and one witness can never prove her fact, but prithee on with thy speech.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why then this fair mistress I must confess.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But he will not confess before witness will he?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Push, did not I tell you he would speak to an oak.

sp.speaker: ●an:
sp.p: Nay, than that will be a strong proof indeed.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Proof, nay, if that be not proof, how say by this token.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: I marry sir, would we had more such tokens of his love.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: This mistress he hath sent to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Look you madam, your husband now makes love to me.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Sir how pert thou art, why look woman, your love a● mad woes me, and to me sent this ring.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And my man the man you so esteem, spite of refusal left with me this cha●e.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: This chain: for ever may he linked be to woe, that hates my love, and woes another so.

sp.speaker: Vvag:
sp.p: Well, let's in, and be but patient all a while, for if the worst do fall, that ever did fall,
A plots in chase that shall out strip them all

div.stage: Enter knight and Cupid before him.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now if she should refuse my jewel and contemn my love, or contemn my love, and take my jewel: what a fool was I to send her a token till I had some token of her affection, as if women might be wooed with gifts, for when we give them those things which most we love, they do esteem we love them better than those things we give, when they poor fools do but deceive themselves, for we do live as merchant's venture, for a treble; again we send them tokens only to get them and their portions. But there comes my persecutor.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Why dost thou haunt me like a ghost, thou female inner: thou hast not holy church in thy power with all hit
commandments, to keep me from thy unhallowed presence: how durst thou break the edict pronounced by the mouth of holy church man? art thou not divorced? is not our separation blown into the people's ears, even by Jehovah's chosen trumpeter? First, thou didst break thy vow to me, and madest of every Priapus a trumpet; on which thou blowedst thine own infamy: therefore avoid, thou leauend lump of sinfulness, avoid.

O my still beloved husband, like filth or dirt, do not flay me like a serpent, which comes to sting thy bosom; I come to kiss; sweet let not suspect divorce me from thy presence, though from thy bed:
For if you will trust this masked face, I know:
No fountain purer than my love would show.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I fly, and hate thee like a serpent's hissing, which comes to sting me with pretence of kissing.

O fainty tears, and feeble hands, for ever may you close, and never part till sharpest grief have cut the heartstrings of my life. Or else let this same brain of mine dissolve to tears, and drop itself even drop by drop, until it make a sea of woes, that therein I may drown my wretched life.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: Alas poor lady, I pity your calamity, and grieve to see you bruised by my master's injury, which makes your eyes like sponges drop these brinish tears, and spoils a face, such as was never better one framed by the skilful hand of nature.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Avoid thou slave, how durst thou woe me? I am like a star to thee; my orb's above thee.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: O! then my love is a most clear and brightest star: look not with a malevolent aspect upon me, but let your eyes bright raise up my life, and so extol my thoughts

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Perish may thyself and love together:
Heavens grant again, I ne'er may hear of either.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Respect her most, that most of all loves you.
sp.p: O! do not turn away those eyes, whose radiant beams first nursed my flame.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: Avoid thou unresistable torturer, more fretting to my thoughts than cankars are to metals. How often have I told thee of my hatred? For of this be thou sure and still remembered: deep hate (Like love) can hardly be dissembled.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Ay, dost thou hate me then? O brightest Venus,
Now or never make thy blind son see; and 〈◊〉 his heart, whose hate hath wounded me.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: O here she is; pray God my band sit well. Fair lady, may I presume with the bee to suck honey from thy lips, for I dreamed the last night.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay, I thought he would woo me dreaming like a Welshman.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: That I was transfigured, metamorphosed, or transformed into a flea in thy bed.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But did I not kill ye then?

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Me thought you did did, but first I dreamt I flung you.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Yet again dreaming, I'll talk no more, but be gone; for fear I wake him.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: And then methought , as I was skipping from your knee unto your thigh, and so forth; you told a gentleman of it, a friend of yours; who most courtly and softly putting in his hand to catch me. Spretious she's gone, sure 'tis the acuteness of my ingenuity, which makes my jests so stinging, as she cannot endure them: I must needs eat some of your new court-water-gruel, to qualify my my invention.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Thou needest not love, speak what thou wilt, if gently thou do speak, thy words to me are much more musical than is a Siren's voice. Orpheus himself could never strain his high stretched strings to such melodious sounds, as when thy voice doth pierce the ear.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: 'Tis but for my wit she loves me: I sent her tricks already: for courtiers must as well thriving be, have noses to smell out, as eyes to see.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Despised, and left alone, filled brim full of grief, and no way to unload me of my cares.
But through these running eyes, in streams of tears.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Whose tears like to a clear, yet poisoned source, have with their vapours through these eyes (The windows to my heart) infected all my thoughts. Thy eyes do shoot forth glances like to stars, though seated in a moist and rainy sky, the which hath wounded even my heart, and I must die; lest Achilles lance-like, healed by your eye.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I pray you seek somewhere else, if you be ill,
For I in surgerie-haue little skill.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: I'll follow my suit, not ceasing till the most of trial,
For he's a fool in love that makes denial.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.p: Here hath been a maze, a round, a whirling in love,
sp.l: How like the spokes of a lady's coach-wheels
They run one after another:
And as of them you see neither,
So none of these can overtake either.
And though you see them thus forsaken,
They shall be married, but mistaken:
Which for performance yet a while,
I must be labouring to beguile.
Only the men, and make them venture,
To run a circle far from centre
Of their hopes; yet for their good,
Where blinded each like hawk in hood,
Shall marry better than they wooed.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Nay madam, it must needs be so, or else the priest will never marry me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And so you would have us all be married masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: True, to which you all may easily persuade your lovers, telling them with my marriage, will be with much the less suspect effected.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But say, who shall know us, when our faces are not seen?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: The better; for then you shall appoint each one of them, to choose you by their own tokens, which you within yourselves shall change: mistress Peg shall wear mistress Nan's ring, mistress Nan your chain, and you mistress pegs jewel.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: But shall they need to come naked too?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O ay, by any means, only for some private reasons unto me, in which persuasion if you will practise that you know, you will prevail.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll do my best most willingly.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.l: Then come madam, let's in: I know it will do.
For this is held a principle in schools,
Love makes not fools wise men, but wise men fools.

sp.p: Nominativo, hic, haec, hoc.
A noun is the name of a thing.
Amo, amas, amavi, amare.
In speech be these eight parts.

sp.speaker: Ma. correction
sp.p: I promise you sir, I had dined forth today, but that you see the weather is cloudy, and the heavens lower on my delights.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I pray you sir, whose son is that bigger boy?

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p:
It is master Parmisin's son the cheesemonger, and the next to him is master Cavetas' son the ferryman,
two very pretty sparks I'll assure you. Tobias Parmasin, come hither Tobias, hold up your head Tobias, and look and you can see a penny in my brow: so, 'tis well done; what part of speech is mentula?
A noun adjective.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And why a noun adjective?
Because it stands not by himself, but it requires another word to be joined with it.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Mark you sir, I teach both substance and meaning; I do not teach as your common people, d, oh, b, a, b, b, bottles; go sit you down again Tobyas, Timothy, come ye hither Timothy: how construe you this verse Timothy? I am, iam, tacturus, sidera summa putes.
I am, iam, oh John, John, putes, do thou put, sidera, summa, cider in summer, tacturus, in tankards.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: A very forward child, I promise ye.

sp.speaker: Ma●st C.
sp.p: Go sit you down again: will you hear them all examined sir?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Moss willingly good good master correction.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Ye shall sir; sir, I have taken as much pains with them, as any poet whatsoever could have done, to make them answer upon their Q. with good action, distinction, and deliberation: ha, ha, ha, how many devils are there?
Number infinite.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Look you sir, there are an infinite number of devils: what is the devil?
A wicked spirit.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the nature of that wicked spirit?
To work mischief.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: On whom doth it work mischief?
On all mankind.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: When hath he most power to work mischief?
When man hath taken his liquor.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: With what visitations then deludes he mankind?
With strange earthquakes.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the man's best comfort?
To sleep and slumber.

sp.speaker: M. correction
sp.p: Look ye now sir, are they not pretty children?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Very pretty, and well taught, I'll assure you sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Sir, I will tell you, notwithstanding all these pains I take with them, yet how unkindly their parents use me: they suffer their younger children to bewray the church-porch: and no longer since then Monday last, came the official, and there being angry with me about other matters, he threw that in my dish, as if I could have helped it: but I answered him sufficiently: for I told him, they that did it, were but the children and the youth, and youth would break out in despite of his nose; or the best man's nose in the parish.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I think ye spend most of your time with your scholars here: ye keep little other company.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Yes sometimes sir, here was yesterday master Nucome the courtier, do you not know him sir?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: O very well sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: He is a fine gentleman, a good scholar, and an excellent naturalist: and truly fell into a great disputation, (Peace these boys there) and our argument was, whether a fool or a wiseman made the best lawyer. He stood for the wise man, and I most scholastically, stood for the fool: and thus I began my syllogism, (Peace these boys when I bid ye) your wiseman (Said I) useth few words, your fool, much babbling; your best lawyers use much babbling. Ergo, your fools makes the best lawyers.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And believe me sir, was well proved.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: A flash, a flash, a foolish school-point, a foolish school-point.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O ay, and confuted me too, only by reason of a scurvy old proverb which says, children and fools do always tell true: but your best lawyers do not always tell true: ergò, your fools make not your best lawyers, a most strong and strange argument.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I pray master correction, let me entreat a playday for your scholars.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: O master wages, they do nothing else, they do nothing but play, nothing but play.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Nay good sir, do not deny me, for I have some private business with you of 〈◊〉 importance.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay then sir you shall prevail indeed: you shall, yet I remember; Dyonisius ille Tyrannus, scyciliae crudelissimus, crudelissimus sciciliae Tyrannus ille Dyonisius: says to one of his pupils: hue ades, haec animo, concipe dictatuo. So I say unto you all my masters, reverere maiores: pluck off your hats to your betters, and look ye give the woman the wall, and so go your ways.

div.stage: Omnes gratias: gratias: gratias: gratias: exeunt omnes scholars.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Morrow mistress correction.

sp.speaker: Mistress correction
sp.p: Morrow good wages.

sp.speaker: Master correction
sp.p: Morrow sweet wife, sweet Frisset, sweet nuptial.

sp.speaker: Mistress correction
sp.p: O master wages! how doth your good master, sir Timothy troublesome? what, doth he think he is a cuckold still?

sp.speaker: Maist. correction
sp.p: An arrant cuckold (Wife) believe it.

sp.speaker: Mistress correction
sp.p: Come, come, husband, you are such another; why do you say so?

sp.speaker: Ma. Corr:
sp.p: Because it is true, wife.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Sir, master correction you are mistaken, I think he be no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cour:
sp.p: Good master wages talk no more of cuckolds; I would they were all in the sea for my part.

sp.speaker: Mr C.
sp.p: Husband, can you swim?

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: No wife, nor I desire not to learn.

sp.speaker: Mr C.
sp.p: I would have you in any case appoint with my husband that I may come masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Peace, that plot is already drawn, master correction, I am sent unto you from my master, who commends his love unto you, entreating you will give your diligent attendance this evening at the church, because himself upon his divorce, is privately to be married to a new wife: three other couples he brings with him, they all come masked, yet I will give you private notice what each one is: only I must desire you not to sail.

sp.speaker: Maist. correction
sp.p: Master wages, your master is the helm by which my labours are governed: and tell him I will steer all the navy of my actions by his directions: and so pray commend me back to him.
Well sir then, till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Mai. Cor.
sp.p: The like to you sir. Come wise, I hope that thou shalt thrive, for as all your cockatrices maintain surgeons by their issues: so doth the priest and midwife agree: I set them together, they make work for thee.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And truly husband, I'll come to their labours, be it at midnight, if they send for me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Doth my tire sit well Nan?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Passing well, I'll assure you madam.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Prithee tell me too, how am I dressed?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why thou art very well dressed too, but basted admirably: for the threads sit in thy gown, marry thou wantest a little cramming.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And that's pity; for I can tell you, I am of myself a rare bit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay then thou art for the serving-men, for your gallants (I can assure you) ride altogether with a snaffle.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, thou hast such a deal of wit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed I had, before I spent it amongst such unthankful persons as you are Peg; but I prithee pin, my gown close before: for it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That I will, but why then dost thou obscure thy bravery? this thy petticoat is a great deal richer then thy gown.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith I, I wear my clothes as your gallants we are their wits, the best side inwards, I scorn to show it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But for all this idle talk, I would we had appointed our marriage to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Then the people would a stood gazing on us, and besides, we should have been like thee in Dutch, subject to every cobbler's interpretation, but now being married in the evening, presently bed time follows.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Phoe, but 'tis not the fashion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Tut, hang fashion, I love it in nothing but my clothes.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why, thou knowest 'tis not the fashion in all places to lie with ones own husband every night. 'slight I had rather lie with a man, and never marry him, then marry a man and never lie with him, come, come, I speak my mind freely, I am none of these simpering wenches that come at every, word and says I forsooth, and no forsooth, and blushes at the sight of a child, it puts her in mind how 'twas made and cries faugh at a wanton lest in a play, and harkens to a bawdy tale in her ear.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis but dishonourable to marry thus in hugger-mugger , men will say we are with child, and are ashamed to show our faces.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Our faces! why our faces I hope do: not show us to be with child, 'tis out bellies shows that, and I hope thou art quick flesh and not dead fish, thou wilt not turn up the white of thy belly, wilt? but prithee tell me, was I not married yesterday?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yesterday, why dost ask?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Because, like a young married woman that's poisoned before she is bawd, I begin to long already.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: For what I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Faith to be a-bed with my husband.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Alas woman, those that are passed child bearing, use too long for that too.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay, but my longing yet methinks stretches a great deal longer, for I long to be a widow, that I might have a new husband: yet not for any concupiscent desires, that I have in the world.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I think so too, but only a desire thou hast to try the difference of men, and therefore I think thou wert best next to marry an old man with a white head, because thou mayest sleep quiet and not be troubled a nights.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By this light I had as live marry a saint Davis' leek, no, no, take this of me, wherever thou seest the snow lie on the mountains, be assured there's no great heat in the valley.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Let me see, I would be a —

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: A priest's wife I warrant ye, because thou wouldst fare costly, and live lazily.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No Nan, then marry a Londoner, for then thou shalt live a life and 'twere a lady, wear thy gold necklace, and go in thy velvet cap every day.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: True, and then when thy husband is a broad in traffic for commodities, in other countries, why thou mayst deal at home for ready money

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: No not a Londoner by no means.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why if they have but a plague amongst them one week they all cry out of a dead time straight, besides, if they receive but a little loss at sea, they break straight, and where the husband breaks, you know the wife can no longer hold out, she must down too for want of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay then marry a soldier, for questionless most of them will use their wives well, for they love their punks exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O but they have a vile salt too, for they always beget their children by day, and then they be squint eyed, for when the father looks one way, and the mother another, to see if anybody come the whilst, how can the child look right?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What sayest thou by a civilian Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
O no, by no means, for most of their posterity have ill luck, for what their fathers get by bawdy courts, they commonly spend it all again in bawdy houses, no and ever I marry again, I'll marry an Irish merchant, because they all speak latin, and indeed are most of them philosophers by fortune: omnia mea mecum porto, for they carry all their ware in their breech: but come, let us make haste
away, I fear out lovers do our coming stay.

div.stage: Enter the old lord, and the merchant.

sp.speaker: Old lord:
sp.p: You see master venture, the greatest comfort that is left me now, is only in my neighbour's loves, where are these knaves there?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: What have they supped within.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Not yet my lord.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: Why so, thou art an honest knave, go see that none want wine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: I would not have the worst complain of scarcity or want of any thing, for master venture we shall carry nothing with us, for naked we into the world came, without that which we now possess and have, and without it we must unto the grave. Enter sir John correction.o sir John, sir John, I thank you for your homely today, but it you have a fault sir John, the which in any of your scholars would deserve a whipping: you are come too late, I and to a feast and all, well, well, well, but you shall fare the worse for this sir John.

sp.speaker: Ma. Co:
sp.p: I would desire a word in private with your honour.

sp.speaker: Old lor:
sp.p: With all my heart:They whisperthey shall be welcome, even exceeding welcome, and I thank you too.

Hark you neighbour, sir John tells me that to honour me in this my predecessors still accustomed feast, four new married couples are hither come in a mask, newly from the church, their feet not yet since their nuptial, have kissed their own thresholds.

div.stage: Enter master correciion, Cupid and the maskers dauncing

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: 'Tis sign ye are well beloved my lord.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: I am indeed master venture, I am indeed.
Gentlemen and women, ye are all welcome even with my heart, I with my heart i'faith. O neighbour venture my son and your daughter now be married, what a joyful mask would this have been.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: 'Tis true my lord, but they are fled beyond all hope of ever seeing them again.

sp.speaker: Old lo.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'tis true, yet though the fruit gone be, my grief you see, like leaves stick 〈◊〉 upon this tree. but come neighbour come, let's sit and look upon this youthful dancing mirth, for youth and mirth have danced themselves out at heels with me.
Nay, pray gentlemen unmask, that we may know to whom we shall be thankful for this honour, how now my son?

div.stage: The first couple unmask and kneel.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: My daughter.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: Now may my blessing raise thee from the ground.

sp.speaker: Ven:
sp.p: And mine make thee both fruitful, and a faithful wife.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: Why what are you?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Mistook of you, but such is woman's fantasy,
Constant in nothing but unconstancy:
For I that first you most abhorred,
Loved you a slave, and hated you a lord.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.l: Well, woodcock like by thy bill, 'tis my hap,
Thus fast to be catched in a woman's trap.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Now by my conscience I am deceived.

sp.speaker: N●.
sp.p: No, not a whit, for I will love you ever.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.l: Well, give me your hand then, since 'tis my fate,
What marriage 〈◊〉, I'll never separate.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O! I repent it not, this match is double made, and twice hath holy Hymen's 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Well, since 'tis thus hence forth I'll love thee ever, for que sera, sera, 'gainst what plots soever , but who is this, master correction?

sp.speaker: Ma. Co.
sp.p: A friend of yours. They unmask.spretious 'tis my wife.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O then sir 'tis a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: Come ye away housewife, come ye from him, come.

sp.speaker: Mi Co.
sp.p: Faith sir no, why is he not my husband? did not you yourself marry me to him? but do you hear, you were best be quiet and let me alone, if not, i'faith I'll tell all.

sp.speaker: Ma. correction
sp.p: Tell what thou canst, justice my lord justice, I beseech ye for justice.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech your lordship too, though I am but a weak vessel called a woman, and therefore by reason of my bashfulness unable sir to set forth mine own tale, yet I doubt not, but I shall find good hearing at your lord ships hand, if ye will but give me leave to open mine own case.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: Speak, what are your grievances.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: May it please your honour in few words, my husband hath four wives, and then I hope 'tis as lawful for me to have two husbands.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: How do you answer this sir John?

sp.speaker: Ma. correction
sp.p: And like your honour, I think 'tis as lawful for me to have four wives, as 'tis for my parson to have four benefices, considering I use them as he doth his benefices, for I protest to your honour, I ne'er came near none of them.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Will not this do it master wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No, you see he hath answered it.

sp.speaker: Mi Co.
sp.p: Nay then and it like your lordship, I may be divorced for another thing, but that I am ashamed to speak on't.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Nay, you must tell what 'tis.

sp.speaker: M. correction
sp.p: Truly I am half ashamed.

sp.speaker: Old lor.
sp.p: Come, come woman, never be a shamed to tell (True.

sp.speaker: Mi: Cor.
sp.p: And I may be so bold to tell your honour in private.

sp.speaker: Old lo.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mi Co.
sp.p: Truly and like your honour, he hath not that a man should have.

sp.speaker: Old. Lo.
sp.p: No, why what doth he want.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay pray your lordship to spare me now, faith I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.p: Nay good mistress correction, I must know what it is.

sp.speaker: Mi Cor.
sp.p: Why then sir I must needs tell: truly 'a hath never a beard.

sp.speaker: Old lord.
sp.l: Indeed a man should have a beard.
Well mistress correction, your husband must have you back again:
And thus in friendship ends long jealous strife,
With all things well, save wages wants a wife.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: But gentlemen, whose judgements sit
In strict commission on the wit:
Which from the author's pen did flow
He wisheth at all but this to know.
That if you well do censure him,
He ready is with brains and pen,
Another time to pleasure you,
If not, he bids you all adieu.
For well he knows he hath done wells
And so he boldly dares to tell.
Yet for the children ere I go,
Your censure I would willing know.
For if you do the action blame.
They ready are with pardon drawn
And each of them here hoping stands
That you will sign it with your hands.
